Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
sulfa
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Vomiting/Diarrhea 

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Cardiac Cath, s/p DES to RCA
 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o woman with a PMH significant for DM and HTN who was 
transferred from ___ for STEMI. She states that 
shortly after awaking at 0800 the morning of admission she 
experienced sudden onset nausea, vomiting and non-bloody non 
melanotic diarrhea with associated diaphoresis. She called her 
PCP, who urged her to go to the ___, where she was found 
to have ST elevations in II/III/AVF and reciprocal ST 
depressions in V2. VS at the time were: T 97.4 BP 131/61 HR 61 
RR 18 O2 Sat 100% RA. She was given ASA 325, Heparin 60U/kg, 
Atorvastatin 80 and Plavix 600 and transferred to ___ for PCI. 

Cardiac cath showed total mid RCA occulsion (R dominant) and a 
DES was placed with restoration of flow to the distal RCA and 
PDA. Labs on arrival were CKMB 61 Trop 1.81 and Cr 1.7 (baseline 
unknown). 

On arrival to the CCU she denied CP/SOB/N/V/HA, palpitations or 
lightheadedness. She has had no sick contacts and states she can 
walk ~30 minutes before becoming SOB. She does not frequently 
climb stairs due to degenerative disc disease. She denies 
PND/orthopnea and states that she has noticed occasional 
swelling in her ankles over the past few months.  

On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or 
rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the 
other review of systems were negative.  

 
Past Medical History:
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Hypertension  
2. CARDIAC HISTORY: None 
3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
- cataracts
- GERD
- osteoporosis
- spinal stenosis
- gastric ulcer
- asthma
- hysterectomy
- cholecystectomy
- multiple back surgeries

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
- No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, 
or sudden cardiac death.  
- Mother: Died at age ___, unclear history of CAD
- Father: ___ at age ___
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM:
VS: T 98 BP 93/48 HR 63 RR 17 O2 Sat 97% 2L NC
Wt 153 lbs
GENERAL: NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate.  
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were 
pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa.  
NECK: Supple, JVP 3cm above the clavicle, thyroid non tender, 
mobile. No LAD.  
CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular 
line. II/VI harsh holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. 
Normal S1/S2, no S3/S4. No lifts of heaves. No carotid bruits.   

LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp 
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTA anteriorly.
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not 
enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits.  
EXTREMITIES: WWP, scant pedal edema to the medial malleolus. 2+ 
pulses bilaterally. Cath site c/d/i, no hematoma or femoral 
bruits.  
PULSES:  
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  

DISCHARGE EXAM:
GEN: NAD
CV: RRR, III/VI holosystolic murmur heart throughout the 
precordium, JVP flat. Normal S1/S2, no S3/S4
PULM: Crackles in dependent lung fields L>R, no increased WOB, 
no cyanosis. 
ABD: NTND, NABS, no rigidity or rebound. 
EXT: WWP, no c/c/e, pulses 2+
NEURO: A/Ox3, non focal. 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:27PM   GLUCOSE-131* UREA N-44* CREAT-1.6* 
SODIUM-131* POTASSIUM-3.9 CHLORIDE-88* TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-19
___ 12:22PM   CK-MB-102* cTropnT-5.04*
___ 05:48AM   CK-MB-120* cTropnT-5.18*
___ 05:48AM   TRIGLYCER-77 HDL CHOL-54 CHOL/HDL-2.9 
LDL(CALC)-90
___ 01:00AM   CK-MB-61* MB INDX-7.5* cTropnT-1.81*
___ 01:00AM   WBC-11.0 RBC-4.12* HGB-12.2 HCT-34.4* MCV-84 
MCH-29.5 MCHC-35.3* RDW-15.5
___ 01:00AM   NEUTS-86.8* LYMPHS-9.8* MONOS-3.1 EOS-0.1 
BASOS-0.1

RELEVANT STUDIES:
Cardiac Cath (___): 
1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system 
demonstrated single vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA, 
LAD, and 
LCx were free of angiographically significant disease. There was 
a 
thrombotic total occlusion of the mid-RCA with no 
collateralization. 
2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal resting systemic 

arterial pressure. 

___ (___): The left atrium is normal in size. Left 
ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There 
is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with 
hypokinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls. There is a 
focal defect in the basal inferior septum on 2D and color 
Doppler with continuous left-to-right flow c/w a post infarction 
ventricular septal defect (VSD). The remaining left ventricular 
segments contract normally. (LVEF 50%). Intrinsic left 
ventricular systolic function may be more depressed given the 
interventricular flow). Right ventricular chamber size and free 
wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) appear 
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion. There is no 
aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The 
mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild to moderate 
(___) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 

CXR (___): Current study demonstrates top normal heart as 
well as bilateral hilar enlargement and pulmonary edema. The 
findings might potentially represent a new acute mitral 
regurgitation with increasing pulmonary venous pressure and 
presence of newly developed pulmonary edema. Small bilateral 
pleural effusions are noted. There is no pneumothorax. 

___ (___): The left atrium and right atrium are normal in 
cavity size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left 
ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the 
basal half of the inferior and inferolateral walls. The 
remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 50-55 %). There is 
a ~1cm basal inferoseptal post infarction ventricular septal 
defect (VSD) with prominent left-to-right flow. Right 
ventricular cavity size is normal with free wall hypokinesis. 
The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels 
are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally 
normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild 
(1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid 
regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension. There is an anterior space which most 
likely represents a prominent fat pad. 

___ (___): The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild 
regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinsis 
of the basal and mid inferior and inferolateral segmets . There 
is a post infarction ventricular septal defect (VSD). Right 
ventricular chamber size is normal. with moderate global free 
wall hypokinesis. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic 
regurgitation is seen. An eccentric, posteriorly directed jet of 
Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Moderate [2+] 
tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary 
artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. 
There is an anterior space which most likely represents a 
prominent fat pad. 

MRI (___)
 
1. Normal left ventricular cavity size with normal global LVEF 
of 65% albeit severely depressed effective forward LVEF of 20%. 
Severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the mid to basal inferoseptal 
and inferior walls. 
2. Transmural of late gadolinium enhancement in the inferoseptal 
wall, and 45% non-transmural late gadolinium enhancement in the 
inferior wall extending into the inferolateral wall, consistent 
with myocardial infarction and low (inferoseptal wall) to 
intermediate (inferior wall) likelihood of functional recovery 
after revascularization. The late gadolinium enhancement 
demonstrates a microvascular obstruction-type pattern. The 
infarct size was quantified at 18.2 g, which represents 21% of 
the total myocardial mass. 
3. Increased T2 signal in these segments, consistent with 
edema/inflammation and acute/subacute timing of infarction 
(within 2 weeks). 
4. Myocardial salvage index, representing the difference between 
the area at risk (T2) and the infarct size (late gadolinium 
enhancement) divided by the area at risk, calculated at 53%. 
5. Infarct-related muscular ventricular septal defect in the mid 
to basal 
inferoseptal wall measuring 7 mm in the long-axis direction, and 
6-9 mm in the short-axis direction (9 mm at the mouth on the 
left ventricular size of the septum, and slightly tapering to 6 
mm on the right ventricular side of the septum). 
6. Ischemic mitral regurgitation with mild posterior leaflet 
tethering. 
7. Normal right ventricular cavity size with depressed RVEF of 
39%. Global 
right ventricular hypokinesis with dyskinesis of the distal 
segments. Late 
gadolinium enhancement in the inferior right ventricular wall, 
consistent with right ventricular myocardial infarction. 
Systolic flattening of the 
interventricular septum, consistent with elevated right 
ventricular systolic pressure. 
8. The indexed diameters of the ascending and descending 
thoracic aorta were normal. The indexed diameter of the main 
pulmonary artery was normal. 
9. Left atrial enlargement. 
10. A note is made of dependent patchy areas of consolidation 
are identified in the lung bases, right greater than left, with 
a focal area of nodularity in the right mid lung measuring 2 cm 
in craniocaudal dimension. However, there is no correlate on 
prior chest radiograph. Findings are likely the sequelae of 
pulmonary edema, though aspiration or pneumonia should be 
considered in the appropriate clinical circumstance. Recommend 
follow-up chest radiograph after acute illness to document 
resolution. A note is also made of punctate non-enhancing 
lesions in both kidneys, likely small simple cysts. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o woman with STEMI and total RCA occlusion s/p DES 
complicated by post-infarct ventricular septal perforation. 

# STEMI: Pt had 100% RCA occlusion just distal to the acute 
marginal takeoff, now s/p DES with restoration of flow to the 
distal RCA and PDA (R dominant). She was started on ASA, Plavix, 
Atorvastatin, metoprolol and lisinopril during her hospital 
course. ___ showed mild regional left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal half of the 
inferior and inferolateral walls. Immediately following PCI she 
was in 2:1 heart block, which subsequently evolved to Wenckebach 
and 1:1 conduction. She remained hemodynamically stable 
throughout and was discharged home with cardiology and PCP 
follow up. 

# VSD: Physical exam on admission to the CCU revealed a new 
III/VI systolic murmur heard thoughout the precordium concerning 
for new VSD/MR. ___ showed VSD, cardiac MRI later showed 3:1 
shunt fraction, normal RV size with free wall hypokinesis and 
elevated PA pressures. Her O2 sat remained >93% on RA throughout 
her course and she was given diuresis for reducing pulmonary 
edema and shunt, and minimizing pulmonary hypertension.  Blood 
pressure was also optimized to decrease afterload and maximize 
forward flow.  The definite treatment will require surgical 
repair of the interventricular septum defect. Percutaneous VSD 
closure may also be an option. 

OUTPATIENT ISSUES:
- F/U WITH CT SURGERY/INTERVENTIONAL CARDIOLOGY
- Adjust lasix 80 mg po qd 
- Should have RHC to assess shunt function which could help 
decide whether patient needs to have her shunt fixed

# A-fib: Pt was found to have a period of unsustained 
symptomatic A-fib, lasting ~30 mins.  This could be a result of 
changes in RA volume and dynamics.  Given patient's already 
compromised CO, atrial kick is necessary to maintain adequate 
MAP.  Amiodarone was started for rhythm control. She was 
continued on metoprolol for rate control.  

CHRONIC DIAGNOSES: 
DM: Pt has documented hx of diabetes, controlled by Pioglitizone 
prior to admission.  She was covered with ISS during this 
hospitalization. She was restarted on pioglitizone prior to 
discharge.

# HTN - Her home Verapamil was held and she was started on 
Metoprolol and Lisinopril with SBP goal in the ___ given the 
lack of mortality benefit of CCB (especially verapamil)
  
# GERD - Patient has a documented history of GERD, and takes 
omeprazole at home. Omeprazole was stopped in setting of plavix 
while ranitidine was started at 150 mg po qhs. 

# HLD: She was started on atorvastatin 80 mg po qdaily (PROVE 
trial) but it was decreased to 40 mg po qdaily given she was on 
multiple medications (amiodarone) which would uptitrate her 
statin dose putting her at risk for rhabdomyolysis. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: 
- Pt maintained a full code during this admission
- Pt has follow up with Dr. ___ in one week and CT 
surgery in 2 weeks
 
Medications on Admission:
- Vit D 50,000U every other ___
- Verapamil 240mg qday
- Omeprazole 20mg qday
- Clonazepam 0.5mg po qhs
- Pioglitizone 30mg qday
- Pregalbin 25mg qday
- Ultram 50mg prn back pain

Extended Care

2. Ventricular-Septal Rupture

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
summary: You were transferred to our hospital for treatment of a heart attack. The blockage in your arteries was opened and a stent was placed in one of your coronary arteries to help keep it open. We also treated you with several medications to reduce the risk of both another heart attack and of your heart becoming weak from having had a heart attack. Your heart also suffered a complication from your heart attack in which one of the walls between the different chambers of your heart ruptured, allowing blood to flow in a direction it normally would not flow. This is a serious complication and requires repair. You were evaluated by our interventional cardiologists as well as our cardiac surgeons who felt that it would be best to postpone correcting this problem until you have had a bit more time to recover from your heart attack. We have changed some of your medications and started you on several new medications.

started about 3 days ago and are more pronounced when he lies 
down. He does not have a history of anything like this before. 
He is not dizziness and has not fainted. There are no sick 
contacts at home. He has had some chills but does not have a

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o M with no significant PMH presents to the ED with 
palpitations likely ___  hyperthyroidism.
.
# Palpitations: Onset 4 days prior to admission. ___ 
enzymes neg x 2, EKG showed sinus tach, unlikely PE as d-dimer 
negative. Normal CXR so no pulm process. Constellation of sinus 
tachycardia, palpitations, and TSH<0.02, Free T4 3.9, T3 354, 
consistent with hyperthyroidism. Propranolol 20 mg TID was 
started which helped reduce patient's HR and provide symptomatic 
relief.  
- Anti-TPO pending at discharge to eval for ___'s 
(***returned high at 204 IU/mL, upper limit normal 35). 
.  
# Leg pain: Patient had presented with vague joint aches in his 
legs, potentially consistent with a viral illness, which he 
reported having over the past week, but had resolved. D-dimer 
negative, also not consistent with DVT symptoms. By morning of 
admission, patient was asymptomatic, with no more leg pain.   
.  
# Elevated LFTs: Likely ___ hyperthyroidism - has been known to 
show increase in AlkP, and rarely cholestasis. 
-needs follow up LFTs

none

summary: You were admitted to ___ for palpitations. Blood tests showed that this was because of a disorder called "hyperthyroidism" - an overactive thyroid. We started you on a medicine to help with the palpitations, but you need to follow up with an endocrinologist in outpatient to address the underlying disease. Your palpitations decreased during your stay.

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ERCP ___
 
History of Present Illness:
___ woman whose PMH includes HTN, heart block s/p pacemaker, 
hyperlipidemia, ___, GERD, CKD stage III, adrenal mass with 
___ syndrome, glaucoma, obesity. Diabetes has been poorly 
controlled over last two weeks for unclear reasons, and she 
developed progressive generalized weakness with unsteady gait. 
No paresthesias. Denies polyuria, polydipsia, dysuria, 
dizziness. Denies N/V/D, URI symptoms, dysuria, or myalgias, or 
other c/o. 

She noted generalized pruritus around the same period. Denies 
jaundice or abdominal pain but has noted unintentional weight 
loss ~30lbs over 6 mos, with poor appetite. She was found to 
have cholestatic pattern of LFTs on ___. CT abdomen on ___ 
showed "considerable biliary ductal dilatation extending to the 
level of the low pancreatic head." No pancreatic mass was seen. 
She presented for ERCP today.

Prior to procedure, glucose was ~500, for which she was treated 
with insulin humalog 15U x 2 doses. She also received 2U regular 
insulin IV during procedure. Glucose gradually decreased to 
~200s. ERCP was performed under MAC, which she tolerated well. 
ERCP showed:
"Normal major papilla. The pancreatic duct was injected while 
attempting to canulate the bile duct. The PD was mildly dilated. 
A pancreatic stent was placed successfully to aid biliary 
cannulation. After a pancreatic stent was placed, cannulation of 
the biliary duct was successful. The intrahepatics were dilated. 
The CBD was dilated to 15 mm. There was a middle CBD floating 
filling defect suggestive of a stone. There was a 1cm distal CBD 
stricture with upstream dilation. There was resistance while 
passing a 11.5 mm balloon through this stricture. A 
sphincterotomy was performed. Cytology samples were obtained for 
histology using a brush in the distal CBD. A 7cm by ___ 
straight plastic biliary stent was placed successfully using a 
Oasis stent introducer kit. There was excellent flow of black 
bile post stent placement. Otherwise normal ERCP to third part 
of the duodenum." She was admitted to the Hospital Medicine 
Service for monitoring.

Currently, pt denies any pain, N/V. Feels same as she has 
recently, weak and itchy. In addition, she reports DOE with 
walking or climbing stairs for last few mos. No CP. She had an 
appointment with her PCP today to evaluate these symptoms, which 
she needs to reschedule. She did not take any of her medications 
this morning except 15U Novolog insulin. ROS otherwise negative.

was not associated with position, eating, breathing and would 
not improve with nitro. The pain was not associated with SOB, 
nausea, vomitting, diaphoresis, or dizziness. However, he would 
complain of occasional dizziness upon standing. The pt was 
concerned that the pain would not go away and went to see his

.

The image quality is good. Left ventricular cavity size is 
normal. Resting and stress perfusion images reveal a mild 
reversible basal inferior wall defect but otherwise uniform 
tracer uptake throughout the left ventricular myocardium. Gated 
images reveal normal wall motion. The calculated left 
ventricular ejection fraction is 65 %. Compared with the study 
of ___, the reversible defect is new.

motion and

cath result, pt has known diffuse PDA disease.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt arrived to the floor complaining of ongoing ___ chest pain. 
An EKG was obtained during the chest pain which showed no 
significant changes from prior EKGs. The patient's pain was 
found to be reproducable by exam. Pt was ruled out for MI with 3 
negative cardiac enzymes and then underwent a P-MIBI which 
showed a mild reversible inferolateral defect that was new since 
the patient's last stress test. After discussion with the 
patient's physician, ___ was made for patient 
to undergo catheterization due to his concern for angina. The 
cath showed no significant coronary artery disease. The 
patient's elevated creatinine was worked up and he was diagnosed 
with chronic kidney disease given the elevated creatinine for ___ 
year and the lack of improvement with significant fluid 
rescuscitation. The patient was watched overnight to check his 
creatinine which was 1.3 in the morning. The patient's chest 
pain was resolved by the morning. His groin site showed no 
hematoma, no tenderness, no bruit with 2+ DP and femoral pulses. 
The patient was discharged chest pain free and in stable 
condition with plan for follow up with Dr. ___.

summary: You were admitted with chest pain and underwent a stress test that showed some abnormalities. However, you also underwent cardiac catheterization that showed your stents are still open, and therefore negative for significant coronary artery disease. Based on that, there was no need for intervention. Based on our clinical impression, the most likely cause for your chest pain is musculoskeletal. Our tests did show that you have mild chronic kidney disease (with a estimated GFR of 51) that did not improve with fluids. You should discuss this with Dr. ___ as well as your primary care physician.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ otherwise healthy man with 5 days of 
fever, HA, nausea of as yet unknown etiology, with bland CSF (1 
WBC) of low concern for aseptic meningitis, now with finding of 
RLL PNA on CT with mild cough but absence of other respiratory 
symptoms being treated with doxycycline and levofloxacin.

#FEVER/COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA - At presentation, the 
patient's fevers to 102-103 in the setting of severe headache 
were concerning for meningitis. He was evaluated by neurology, 
however, CSF with 1WBC was not concerning for meningeal 
infection. Workup revealed mildly positive UA with elevated 
protein and spec ___, but negative nitrites and leukocyte 
esterase; in the absence of dysuria UTI was thought very 
unlikely. The patient was evaluated by infectious disease and an 
extensive workup was sent for tick-borne illnesses and 
arboviruses; this revealed neg Lyme, HIV, Ehrlichia, EBV, CMV, 
CSF gram stain and culture, with further tests (Rickettsia, 
Leptospira) pending. The patient was started on a 14-day course 
of IV doxycycline as empiric treatment for tick-borne bacterial 
illness. CXR in the ED revealed subtle RLL infiltrate and 
___ LAD, however since he was without cough or other 
respiratory symptoms and with good O2 sat on room air, pulmonary 
infection was thought unlikely. When his fevers, headache, and 
nausea had not significant improved on the doxycycline by HD2, 
he underwent non-contrast chest CT as follow-up for his CXR. 
This revealed a dense RLL pneumonia with reactive mediastinal 
LAD. He was started on a 7-day course of IV levofloxacin for 
community-acquired pneumonia. He was unable to produce an 
induced sputum sample without oropharyngeal contamination. He 
developed a mild cough but his respiratory status otherwise 
remained stable and his fever curve trended downwards and by 
discharge he had been afebrile for over 36 hours. Blood cultures 
x4 and urine cultures x2 remained negative. He was transitioned 
to PO antibiotics with planned total course of levofloxacin for 
7 days (last day ___ and doxycycline for 14 days (last day 
___ and discharged home afebrile and in stable condition. 

#HEADACHE - The patient was admitted to the service with severe 
headache, thought to be mainly post-LP headache combined with 
effects of his illness and fever. He had initially complained of 
photophobia on admission but this quickly resolved. His pain was 
controlled with alternating IV morphine and IV dilaudid along 
with Fioricet, with care not to exceed maximum doses allowed for 
his renal impairment and transaminitis.  Dilaudid was ultimately 
discontinued as it was contributing to his nausea and vomiting.  
Once he was taking POs, he was transitioned to oxycodone and 
fioricet. He had initially complained of increased pain with 
sitting up, so anesthesia was called for potential blood patch 
for post-LP headache, however they were reluctant to do this 
while he was febrile. His headache improved on oxycodone and 
fioricet and he rated it as ___ before discharge. He was 
discharged home with 10 tablets of 5mg oxycodone along with 
acetaminophen for residual headache.  It is anticipated that his 
headache will continue to improve overtime, and he was advised 
to take narcotics only when necessary and to taper use of it to 
prevent potential rebound headache.

#ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: The patient presented with increased 
Creatinine to 2.1 (baseline 1.05 -1.3) likely due to 
intravascular volume depletion/pre-renal given low  FeNa, ___ 
several days of nausea and vomiting and decreased PO intake.  In 
addition, he was found to have elevated CK.  Patient was given 
IVF while in the hospital.  His Cr improved over the course of 
admission to 1.3. Renally cleared medications were minimized 
during his admission and he had good urine output throughout his 
stay.  He was adviced to avoid taking the OTC supplement while 
he continues to have ARF.

#TRANSAMINITIS - The patient presented with a mild transaminitis 
of ALT 115 AST 79 (baseline: normal LFTs) and normal TBili, with 
subsequent improvement to AST and ALT in the ___. The patient 
initial mild RUQ tenderness which quickly resolved. He had a 
negative viral hepatitis panel, mildly elevated ferritin to 531 
(likely acute phase reaction), and negative ___ and ANCA. RUQ 
ultrasound was unremarkable except for one 9mm hepatic cyst. The 
elevation in enzymes was thought likely due to regular home use 
of several supplements, the safety profiles of which are 
unknown. The patient's ALT and AST remained generally stable 
throughout admission.  He was recommended to avoid taking his 
OTC supplements while he continues to have transaminitis to 
avoid potential further injury.

#RHABDOMYOLYSIS.  Likely related to the underlying infectious 
etiology.  Improved with fluid hydration.  

#NAUSEA - The patient had significant nausea throughout his 
hospital stay, likely ___ PNA and fever, and later thought to be 
aggravated by IV hydromorphone that was used for headache. His 
nausea was treated with IV ondansetron and phenergan and PR 
prochlorperazine with good response. His diet was slowly 
advanced and by discharge he was tolerating solid food. He was 
discharged with PO ondansetron and promethazine for residual 
nausea at home.

summary: You were admitted to the ___ on ___ for fever, headache, and nausea. You were evaluated by neurology, who performed a lumbar puncture which showed low suspicion for meningitis, however, there was suspicion that your symptoms were caused by a a viral infection or an infection that you could have contracted from a tick bite or mosquito bite. Testing was sent off for these possible viral illnesses and you were started on the antibiotic doxycycline. A chest x-ray done when you were admitted showed enlarged lymph nodes, and a follow-up CT scan of your chest revealed a pneumonia (lung infection) in the right lung. You were started on the antibiotic levofloxacin to treat a community-acquired pneumonia. Your fever, headache, and nausea have improved. You will be going home on doxycycline for a total of 14 days and levofloxacin for a total of 7 days. You should avoid taking over the counter supplements given recent liver and kidney injury. You should avoid drinking alcohol until your liver returns to normal. You should avoid taking medications such as ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, etc.

summary: You were transferred from ___ to ___ after you presented there with a myocardial infarction (heart attack). You had a heart catheterization, which showed blockages in your right coronary artery. Three stents were placed to open the blockage, and improve blood flow to your heart. You were started on Aspirin and Plavix. Aspirin and Plavix are used to decrease the risk of clot formation in your stent. You will take Aspirin indefinitely, and Plavix for at least one year. Do not stop taking Plavix until told to do so only by your Cardiologist. Stopping Plavix prematurely may increase your risk of a life threatening heart attack. After your procedure, your heart rate and blood pressure were unstable, so you were closely monitored overnight in the CCU. You were transferred out to the floor when you were stable. You were also started on Atorvastatin to manage your heart disease and cholesterol. Your lipid panel and liver function will be monitored periodically.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a very pleasant ___ yo female with no known PMHx 
who presents on transfer from ___ where she came 
on night of ___ with altered mental status and was found to 
have profound leukocytosis and anemia. At that time, her WBC 
count was 397, HgB 3.3, LDH 781, haptoglobin <10 and she was 
transferred to ___ MICU for further treatment. She was treated 
with high dose steroids and 4 U pRBCs as well as rasburicase and 
allopurinol for hyperuricemia. She did not receive 
plasmaphoresis in the MICU, as it is likely that her AMS was due 
to profound anemia rather than leukostasis. Troponins were also 
positive in the ICU which is thought to be most consistent with 
type II NSTEMI in the setting of profound anemia. CT abdomen 
revealed diffuse lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear and flow 
cytometry were consistent with new diagnosis of chronic 
lymphocytic leukemia. Direct coombs was positive for IgG (3+), 
warm hemolytic anemia. G6PD negative. She has been treated with 
Rituxan (beginning ___ and Bendamustine (beginning ___ as well 
as high dose steroids. Hemolysis labs (LD and Tbili) have 
subsequently improved and we have started to taper her steroids. 
Her hyperuricemia has also resolved with treatment and 
allopurinol discontinued. 

Additionally, while admitted she began complaining of increased 
pain in lower extremities, so a Doppler U/S was ordered. U/S on 
___ showed completely occlusive thrombus within the left 
popliteal vein and also areas of thrombosis bilaterally in the 
calf veins. Patient had not been on prophylactic anticoagulation 
previously due to thrombocytopenia. There was some concern that 
this thrombosis was secondary to HIT but heparin antibodies are 
negative. She received 2 days of Fondaparinux while HIT was a 
consideration. Once workup was negative she was started on 
Lovenox BID.

summary: You were admitted to ___ when you were found to be confused and more tired than normal at home. There, your red blood cell count was very low and you were transferred to ___ for further treatment. Here, we found that you have leukemia. Leukemia is a disease which causes your body to make too many white blood cells which don't work correctly. These abnormal white blood cells can cause your body to start breaking down your red blood cells. This is why you had such a low red blood cell count when you came into the hospital. To treat your leukemia we gave you two medications through your veins called Rituximab and Bendamustine. You tolerated these medications very well. These medicines have helped decrease the number of abnormal white blood cells that you have in your blood. We also gave you steroids. These steroids have slowed down the your body from breaking down your red blood cells. You still are breaking down your red blood cells, but much more slowly than when you came into the hospital.

summary: You were admitted from your rehab facility because you had blood in your stool You received a blood transfusion because your counts were too low. We temporarily stopped your blood thinner because we were concerned about your bleeding. This was restarted after your blood counts seemed to stabilize. You had an endoscopy and colonoscopy done to try and find the source of your bleeding. These tests did not find the cause of your bleeding. You then underwent a capsule study which found a few shallow ulcers in your stomach. This study may need to be repeated in the future. You should return to the hospital if you notice any more blood in your stool.

Your medications were adjusted to include an acid suppressing agent and medications to reduce your hiccups. You refused this line, therefore we recommend one week of oral antibiotics. If you have any fever, chills, or feel sick, you should be transferred to a hospital to return to IV treatment. You should have blood cultures checked ___ days after you finish treatment to be sure the infection in your bloodstream has resolved. Finally, you will need to take a low-dose daily antibiotic to prevent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, which can lead to bloodstream infection.

summary: You were admitted for acute onset right leg pain, concerning for fracture. You underwent multiple imaging studies including CT scan and x-rays of your leg, which did not show evidence of fracture or dislocation. You also had ultrasound to exclude blood clot. Your muscle enzymes were normal and did not suggest serious muscle damage. Your pain is most likely musculoskeletal pain. You were seen by the physical therapists, and they recommended rehab. You also had low sodium levels, likely from mild dehydration. This improved with fluids. You were noted to have bacteria in your urine, although you did not have symptoms consistent with urinary tract infection. Nonetheless, you were treated with a course of antibiotics by mouth.

SUMMARY STATEMENT

Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with a past medical history 
of hyperlipidemia who presented to the ED after a transient 
episode of monocular vision changes at home prompting ED visit, 
he was admitted to the Neurology Stroke service and ruled out 
for acute stroke. 

#Vision changes:
Patient reports a brief episode of right-sided vision changes at 
home after standing, lasting approximately 30 seconds. Described 
as the "right side of the room was cut in half", no true vision 
loss. Immediately prior to this, he experienced some dizziness 
and lightheadedness while sitting, when attempting to stand he 
drifted forward and caught himself without an actual fall. His 
symptoms resolved after standing. He went to the ED and his 
symptoms were largely resolved, his NIHSS was 0. His general and 
neurologic review of systems was otherwise unremarkable. His 
neurologic exam was notable for poor vision (right ___, left 
___, blurry right-sided vision when left eye covered, full 
visual fields, normal fundoscopic exam, slight right arm 
pronation, and slightly wide based gait (see below #gait 
disorder). He had a brain MRI that was negative for acute or 
prior stroke (notably, ADC demonstrated questionable bright 
lesion in L basal ganglia area, per review with neuroradiology 
likely volume averaging, not stroke), CTA does with significant 
carotid atherosclerosis. While his monocular symptoms are 
certainly concerning for transient ischemic event, particularly 
an atherothrombolic event, this is unlikely given reassuring 
visual exam and MRI, as well as a history that does not suggest 
true vision loss. His serum risk factors for stroke were LDL 91, 
HgA1c 5.5. He was started on aspirin and his home simvastatin 
dose was increased. Other explanations for his vision changes 
include poor baseline vision given age. Low suspicion for 
amaurosis fugax per description of event, or temporal arteritis 
given normal inflammatory markers and lack of headache, temporal 
pain. Given low suspicion for ischemic event, ophthalmology 
evaluated the patient and found no occular pathology.

#Gait disorder
#Peripheral Neuropathy
Patient with longstanding history of mild peripheral neuropathy 
of unclear etiology and gait instability. He is seen in as an 
outpatient in neurology clinic (Dr. ___. His symptoms are 
largely thought to be related to anxiety, as they are 
subjectively out of proportion to his examination findings. On 
admission, his gait was slightly wide based, he states this is 
chronic. His A1c of 5.5 does not suggest diabetic neuropathy, 
although he is close to pre-diabetic range. Notably, he is a 
daily drinker ___ beers per day), and this may be contributory.

#HLD
Increased home statin dose as above.

# PNEUMOTHORAX: Patient developed a left-sided PTX s/p lung 
biopsy, and
had ___ left-sided chest tube placed on ___ that was ultimately 
removed ___ pain, with repeat CT chest showing only a small PTX. 
Serial CXRs on ___ and ___ showed stable small residual left 
apical PTX. She remained hemodynamically stable and satting well 
on room air. Lungs clear bilaterally, with good air movement 
throughout at time of discharge. After discussion with ___, they 
had reviewed his multiple chest x-rays and felt that she was 
stable to go home without need for follow up.

narcotics contract. Per old OMR note, Dr. ___ (her 
PCP) wanted to taper her oxycodone, however she wasn't in 
agreement and so left the room without finishing the visit. Per 
___, last script for oxycodone was filled ___. Of note, 
has acute pain in setting of recent chest tube placement and has 
severe intermittent chest pain - however ECG reassuring, 
Trops/CKMB negative, lactate wnl, and has had multiple CXRs w/o 
progression of residual small apical pneumothorax. Per ___, her 
degree of pain seems out of proportion to what they would expect 
post-procedurally. Of note, may have low pain tolerance in the 
setting of high opioid requirement given her prior 
narcotic abuse. Pain improved over 24 hours with Tylenol and 
slow improvement in incisional site pain.

Acetaminophen 650 mg PO/NG Q8H

TraMADol 50 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Severe

resolved within 15 minutes. Head CT without acute process. Neuro 
exam on admission is completely normal. Etiology was most likely 
due to medications and pain. TIA is possible, but seems less 
likely given acute resolution of symptoms. No concern for 
ongoing CVA. Having said this, upon consultation with neurology 
they recommended an MRI brain to ensure there was no metastatic 
disease in the setting of her lung nodule of unknown etiology. 
Her discharge neurologic exam demonstrated no focal neurologic 
deficits with normal cranial nerve exam, normal strength exam 
and normal gait. In discussion with Dr. ___ telephone,

You were given so much pain medicine that you were having difficulty talking and there was concern that you were having a stroke. demonstrated a R occipital stroke and a L vertebral dissection.

at an unusual angle which may have been the
trigger of the dissection. He does not have physical stigmata of
a collagen vascular disorder. No family hx of such either. MRA 
brain/neck was not supportive of fibromuscular dysplasia.

gtt/warfarin with him (discussed ___ study results regarding 
management strategies for patients with stroke due to 
dissection). He agreed

to aspirin.

sports, and
avoid rapid turning of the neck for the next six months.

said that he could continue to operate a motor vehicle. He 
should follow up with a Neuro-ophthomologist.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital because of acute onset vision loss affecting the left upper quadrant of your vision. We found on imaging that you had a small stroke in your right occipital lobe that likely explains these symptoms. We also found a dissection (tear in the wall) of your left vertebral artery. You most likely experienced this year because of craning your neck while working. We expect that your vision loss should improve over time. We started you on a heparin drip to decrease the risk of further strokes related to this dissection. Before discharge, you were transitioned to aspirin. You may experience some continued soreness in your neck in the next few days/weeks. Be careful with movements that may further stretch or arch your neck in the future. Try not to carry more than 20 lb over your head.

Brief Hospital Course:
=======
SUMMARY
=======
___ w/ PMH HTN, DM2, AFib (on warfarin) who presented with left 
leg swelling (L>R) and 2 days of left leg pain and found to have 
a LLE DVT iso subtherapeutic INR. Started heparin gtt and 
transitioned to apixaban. 

ACUTE ISSUES
=============
#Left femoral, popliteal DVT Treatment
Per records, patient has a long-standing history of atrial 
fibrillation but was not on anticoagulation until 2 weeks ago 
when he was started after a preop evaluation for cataract 
surgery. Patient was never therapeutic on warfarin despite 
increasing doses up to 15 mg daily. He presented to the ED on 
___ with 3 days of worsening lower extremity swelling and left 
leg erythema and pain. Doppler US w/ occlusive thrombus in the 
mid and distal left femoral vein and popliteal vein, 
nonocclusive thrombus in the proximal left femoral vein and 
proximal left deep femoral vein. He was started on a heparin 
drip in the ED and vascular surgery was consulted for possible 
thrombectomy. Patient had good perfusion and easily palpable 
pulses in distal extremities and therefore vascular did not feel 
any need for urgent thrombectomy. Recommended medical treatment. 
Patient was admitted to medicine and was transitioned from 
heparin drip to apixaban given difficulty in achieving 
therapeutic INR on warfarin. Of note, apixaban has not been 
studied in patients weighing greater than 120 kg. However, 
apixaban is not lipophilic and therefore pharmacologically 
should not differ in patients with obesity. Did not fail 
warfarin as was never therapeutic on this medication. Given 
difficulty with achieving therapeutic INR despite very high 
doses, and per discussion with pharmacologist, felt that safest 
option was for apixaban. 

#AFib
Per records, appears to have been diagnosed by his PCP in 
___ several years back. However, patient was not started on 
anticoagulation at that time. Was recently started on warfarin 2 
weeks ago by new PCP who saw him for a preop evaluation for 
cataract surgery. Will continue on apixaban as above 
indefinitely for a chads vasc score of 3. Continue rate control 
with labetalol.

#LLE Cellulitis
Presented with LLE erythema and warmth which is on the shin, not 
so much the calf. Patient without fevers, leukocytosis, signs of 
skin breakdown. No concern for joint involvement. Will complete 
5 day course of cephalexin for presumed cellulitis. 

#___
#CAD s/p PCI with two stents placed
No history of CHF per patient. Does have a recent TTE done ___ 
weeks ago which showed EF 65% w/ small area of akinesis in 
distal inferior/inferoseptal walls. Patient did complain of 3 
days of worsening lower semi-swelling but this was also in the 
setting of recently starting amlodipine. No other symptoms of 
CHF and no other signs on exam. Received 40 IV Lasix in the ED 
but held further diuresis as felt well.

CHRONIC ISSUES
===============
#HTN
Continue home amlodipine, Lisinopril, labetalol

#DM2
Continue metformin

#CAD
S/p 2 stents about ___ years ago. Continue home labetalol 
aspirin, atorvastatin

#CKD stage II
Likely due to HTN, DM2. Appears to be at baseline

#Hypothyroidism
Continued home levothyroxine

===================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
===================
[] DVT: Patient will continue on apixaban 10 mg twice daily for 
the next 7 days and then transition to 5 mg twice daily 
indefinitely for treatment of DVT as well as atrial 
fibrillation. 
[] LLE Cellulit patient will continueis: Keflex for a total of 5 
days for uncomplicated left lower extremity cellulitis.
[] Lower Extremity Swelling: ___ be related to amlodipine. 
Consider switching to a different antihypertensive if continues 
to worsen. Less likely due to heart failure exacerbation given 
lack of other symptoms or signs.
[] Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology. Triamterene was held prior 
to admission. We are continuing to hold this medication. Patient 
should follow-up with endocrinology as outpatient for further 
workup.

Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery team and underwent CT 
imaging of her abdomen showing closed loop obstruction or 
transmesenteric internal hernia complicated by small bowel 
ischemia. She was made NPO and given IV fluids. It was discussed 
with her that operative repair was indicated; she was prepped, 
consented and taken to the operating room on her first hospital 
day for exploratory laparotomy with lysis of adhesions. There 
were no complications.

Postoperatively she progressed slowly in terms of return of 
bowel function. Her NG was removed on POD# 2 and she was kept 
NPO for 24 hours. Her diet was advanced very slowly starting 
with sips and eventually to solids for which she was able to 
tolerate. 

She did have urinary retention after Foley catheter removal on 
POD#2 requiring that her catheter be replaced. Another voiding 
trial was attempted on the POD#3 and she voided on her own 
initially. On POD #4 she was noted with very little urinary 
output with bladder distention and was bladder scanned for >800 
cc's; the Foley was replaced again. Flomax was started as well.

She was started on Unasyn for blood cultures that grew 
CORYNEBACTERIUM SPECIES; repeat blood cultures were sent and 
there was no growth as of ___. The antibiotics were discontinued 
on ___.

Her pain was well controlled with oral narcotics and she is 
ambulating independently.

She is being discharged to home and will follow up with her PCP 
and in the Acute Care Surgery clinic as scheduled.   Patient 
will be sent home with foley in place and plan to f/u with 
urology as an outpatient.  Appointment was provided at time of 
discharge.  Foley care teaching was provided and patient 
declined ___ services.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is an ___ yo ___ woman with a h/o HTN who presents after 
one episode of dizziness, found to be in hypertensive urgency in 
the ED with second degree heart block.

#Pre-syncope- After much discussion amongst the EP team, it was 
decided that the EKG's and telemetry appear to show ___ type 
I (___) second degree heart block.  Interestingly, the 
EKG's appear largely unchanged from ___.  Based on this 
inofrmation, it is unlikely that the episode of 
dizziness/pre-syncope was caused by heart block, but more likely 
caused by prolonged fasting for religious reasons.  Further, EP 
discussed the possibility of a pacemaker with the pt and she 
declined all evaluation for pacemaker placement.

#Hypertension:  Pt had hypertensive urgency in the ED with 
systolic BP's to the 220's.  Pt remained hypertensive on the 
floor with morning SBP's in the 220's, although the pt was 
completely asymptomatic and BP's consistently trended downward 
to SBP's in the 150's/160's in the evening without intervention, 
as the pt refused po medications during the day.  Looking at 
previous ED admisions, it was apprarent that this was a chronic 
issue.  We restarted pt on hctz 25 mg daily, losartan 100 mg and 
added amlodipine 5 mg daily.  Coreg, which the pt was listed as 
taking, was held because of concern for bradycardia.  On 
discharge pt's BP had decreased to 160/75 with the addition of 
amlodipine.

Transitional Issues:

Pt was instructed to f/u with her PCP within one week to have 
her BP checked and will likely will need additional 
anti-hypertensives for adequate control.

# Orthostatic hypotension: In this patient with IDDM w/ 
neuropathy, orthostasis is likely ___ to autonomic dysfunction, 
although a component of hypovolemia was initially considered. 
She was given 1L NS in the ED. Patient was notably orthostatic 
(160s/80s supine to 85/palp standing) on presentation on the 
floor with no signs of hypovolemia on physical exam. Treatment 
with fludricortisone was considered, but due to concern about 
lower extremity edema (which has been severe in the past), she 
was started on midodrine 5mg PO QAM in discussion with Dr. 
___, her outpatient neurologist. Though her 
symptoms improved somewhat, she still was significant 
orthostatic, so the midodrine was titrated up to 7.5 mg q4-6h 
during the day. Her metoprolol tartrate 75mg PO QHS was 
continued and captopril 12.5mg PO QHS was started on this 
admission. All antihypertensives were held during the day. The 
head of the patient's head was elevated ___ degrees at night 
to help with supine hypertension. Her symptoms and orthostatics 
were monitored throughout her hospital course, and she was 
discharged with the addition of midodrine and captopril.
.

fracture and leg pain ___ peripheral neuropathy. Gabapentin was 
discontinued on the day of admission by outpatient neurologist 
due to concerns about edema and decreased kidney function. She 
was put on a fentanyl patch and duloxetine on ___, however she 
developed intense leg pains that were refractory to treatment 
with oxycodone and tramadol. The fentanyl patch was 
discontinued, and gabapentin 300mg PO BID was restarted after 
consulting with her neurologist. The patient was discharged on 
gabapentin and duloxetine for pain control.  She will need close 
follow up with Dr. ___ neurology to see if these 
medications are adequately controlling her pain and if 
gabapentin needs to be weaned again in the future.

.

___., 37 in ___., 32 now) likely secondary to CKD. Labs show a 
normocytic anemia with no markers of hemolysis. Low retic of 1.1 
suggests underproduction. Iron studies were WNL. We recommend 
consideration of Epogen as an outpatient.
.

Levemir. Her blood glucose was controlled on this admission with 
Humalog SS and Glargine, and FBG was monitor QACHS.
.
# Gastroparesis: Patient controls gastroparesis at home with 
promethazine, which was continued on this admission. We 
recommend consideration of EGD and gastric emptying study as an 
outpatient.
.

before bed on this admission and added captopril before bed (see

resting and not moving.  The last 2 days, the symptoms have been 
near constant, with nausea and vomiting, prompting his
presentation.   

Over the last few years, Mr. ___ has alsohad episodes of double 
vision- for example seeing people's lips above or below when 
watching people on TV.  He also had difficulty reading due to 
double vision.  He obtained glasses which has helped with his 
reading, though he continues to see double at times.  He never 
tried covering one eye or the other, but on doing so during this
interview, he says it is still double with one eye.  He also 
reports a time when he has felt like things were moving (he 
describes trying to catch a baseball which looke like it was 
moving up and down).  He has had difficulty walking, stating he 
is often unsteady and feels like he leans in all directions.  He 
was attributing this to an old ankle fracture.  He reports
constant tinnitus for more than a year.  He denies any hearing 
loss.  He denies any recent head trauma though reports being hit 
in the head years ago during a mugging.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ yo right handed man with several months of 
increasingly frequent episodes of vertigo and nausea.

Whether the patient had a central or peripheral etiology to his 
vertigo and diplopia remained unclear. Therefore, he underwent 
an extensive work-up, including an LP, MRI and CTA. All of these 
studies were normal (see results section) making a central 
etiology unlikely. He continued to improve symptomatically 
during his hospitalization. It was also noted that his double 
vision was present in both monocular and binocular vision 
raising the possibility that his double vision was due to 
primary eye issues and not directly related to his vertigo. 

The patient continued to do well and was discharged in good 
condition. He has follow-up with neurology and should continue 
to treat his nausea associated with dizziness symptomatically.

You will go home on all the same medicines that you came in on. You should also consider seeing an eye doctor as your double vision may be related to dry eyes or similar.

summary: You were admitted because of bacteria in the urine, but it is not uncommon to find bacteria in the urine of patients with long-term foley catheter. In this particular case, you DO NOT have a urinary tract infection. The pain in your groin is due to a fungal infection on your penis and probably also due to irritation of having a foley catheter in place all the time. Your foley was checked and there was no blockage or blood clots. You should continue with your bi-weekly foley catheter changes. Solutions ot this problem include treatment of the infection for which an antifungal powder is being prescribed. It is VERY important that you keep your groin as clean and dry as possible to treat the infection. A suprapubic catheter, as suggested by your urologist may also improve your comfort. You should discuss this with your urologist regarding details of the procedure and whether or not it may be reversible.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of DLBCL on R-CHOP, ESRD on HD 
(MWF), diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation (not on

#Acute on chronic systolic HF: TTE on admission with newly 
depressed EF to 30% with global hypokinesis, concerning for 
doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy (although tachy-mediated 
cardiomyopathy also possible given new AF). Cardiology 
consulted, recommended continuing home meds irbesartan and 
metoprolol. Volume was managed with HD. He received adjusted 
chemotherapy due to concern for toxicity.
Discharge weight: 117 kg

# DLBCL: Stage IIIA large cell lymphoma, presented s/p C2 of 
R-CHOP. High-intermediate risk given age, performance status and 
multiple sites of disease with CR estimated at 56%, ___ year OS of 
37%. Unusually, pt's LDH was wnl, raising possibility of 
indolent lymphoma (e.g. in spleen, bone) transforming to 
high-grade lymphoma with masses in R iliopsoas and obturator 
internus. The patient received 2 days of rituxan/bendamustine on 
___ and ___. He received two doses of neupogen on ___ and ___ 
prior to discharge, with plan for Onc f/u on ___ to receive 
neulasta.

# ESRD on HD (MWF): Continue home sevelamer, calcitriol, and 
calcium carbonate. Patient received ultrafiltration for 
management of acute CHF, and continued with his regularly 
scheduled MWF dialysis. 

# Anemia of chronic disease with contribution of marrow 
suppression from chemo: Stable throughout admission.

# Atrial fibrillation: Continued home metoprolol for rate

INTERPRETATION: ___ yo man with HTN, HL, type II DM, s/p MI, CVA 
and

during the

response to the Persantine infusion was appropriate.

patient was administered 125 mg Aminophylline IV.

report sent separately.

The image quality is adequate with some patient motion 
Left ventricular cavity size is normal. 
Rest and stress perfusion images reveal a mild reversible defect 
in the basal inferior wall but otherwise uniform tracer uptake 
throughout the left ventricular myocardium.  
Gated images reveal normal wall motion.  
The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 51%.  
Compared with the study of ___efect is 
more conspicuous. 
  
IMPRESSION: 
Mild reversible defect of the basal inferior wall in patient 
with known right coronary artery tandem disease. LVEF of 51%. 

Cath: 
1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system 
demonstrated LMCA 
and three vessel disease. The LMCA was heavily calcified with a 
mid 50% 
stenosis and a distal 40% stenosis.  The LAD was heavily 
calcified with 
an ulcerated 75% stenosis in the mid vessel and diffuse disease 
in the 
mid-distal vessel up to 40-50%. A high D1 branch had a 80-90% 
stenosis 
at its origin and a high D2 branch had a 50% stenosis at its 
origin. The 
LAD gave apical collaterals to the RV branch on right. The LCx 
had an 
ostial 50% stenosis with a patent stent in the mid AV groove 
LCx. There 
was moderate disease in a major LPL branch. The RCA had a ___ 

stenosis at its origin (despite IC NTG) without pressure 
dampening. 
There was a patent stent in the proximal-mid RCA with a mid 35% 
stenosis 
in the RCA. The R-PDA had diffuse disease up to 50-60%.  The 
RPL1 had a 
proximal-mid 50% stenosis. RPL3 had an 80% stenosis in its first 
branch 
and pulsatile flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. 
The RV/AM 
branch appeared to have a recanalized tubular stenosis at its 
origin. 
2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed mildly elevated left 
ventricular filling pressures with an LVEDP of 17 mmHg. There 
was normal 
systemic arterial systolic blood pressure with an SBP of 124 
mmHg. There 
was marked respiratory variation in LVEDP from ___s LVSP 
with a pulsus of approximately 25 mmHg. 
3. There was no pressure gradient between the left ventricle and 

ascending aorta to suggest aortic stenosis. 
  
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
1. LMCA and three vessel CAD. 
2. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 
3. Marked respiratory variation in LVSP and LVEDP. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT: ___ yo M with h/o CAD s/p PCI, CVA, DM2 presents with 
Chest Pain and Neck Pain.  
  
## Chest pain: Patient was ruled out for an acute ischemic event 
with two sets of negative cardiac enzymes and negative ECG 
changes.  He had no further pain in his chest after pain 
resolved in the ED with NG.  However, given TIMI risk score ___, 
pt underwent pharmacologic stress test.  Stress test showed 
reversible defect in the inferior wall and patient underwent 
catheterization which showed progressive cardiac disease, 
however, nothing required intervention.  Per cardiology team - 
pt shoudl be medically managed with outpatient cardiology.  If 
he is to become symptomatic he may require CABG in future. He 
was continued on statin, ASA, BB, ACEI.  He also received a 
nutrition consult for diet control. He will require more 
agressive managment of cholesterol and diabetes.  Atenolol was 
increased prior to discharge to improve BP control. 
.  
## Neck pain/Headache: Initial CT scan in the ED showed artifact 
that could not exclude hemorrhage.  Rpt CT scan showed no change 
from prior.  Neuro exam was unremarkable.  Pain improved with 
low dose oxycodone.  CTA also excluded vertobrobasilar 
thrombosis.  His pain was considered to be musculoskeletal after 
above workup was completed. Pt was discharged on tyelnol for 
pain control. 
. 
## Post discharge f/u: 
- f/u BP, atenolol increased to 75mg daily, titrate meds to goal 
BP = 120/80
- consider changing to more potent statin LDL < 70
- nutrition counseling
- consider increasing metformin for improved glycemic control.

The catheterization showed worsening disease but nothing which required intervention. It is important to take care of your heart by following a low sodium, low fat, low cholesterol diet. left glenohumeral joint and moderate osteoarthritis of the left 
acromioclavicular joint.

LEFT ELBOW:   
Again noted is a mildly displaced comminuted fracture of the 
surgical neck of the left humerus. No fractures or joint space 
abnormalities are noted at the left elbow although the lateral

the left

___. 

3. SINGLE FRONTAL VIEW OF THE PELVIS: There is moderate 
degenerative change of the lower lumbar spine as well as 
moderate narrowing of both hip joints. No fracture or 
dislocation is noted. Vascular calcifications are seen. 
IMPRESSION: Moderate degenerative change of both hip joints and 
the lower lumbar spine. No fracture or dislocation. 

4. CT HEAD: There is no evidence of hemorrhage, edema, mass, 
mass effect, or infarction. The ventricles and and sulci are 
moderately prominent, unchanged since the ___ 
examination, reflective of diffuse cortical atrophy. There is 
persistent hypoattenuation of the periventricular white matter, 
compatible with chronic microvascular ischemic disease. No 
fracture is seen. Moderate atherosclerotic calcifications of the 
imaged portion of the ICAs are seen bilaterally. A tiny mucus 
retention cyst is present within the left maxillary sinus. The 
remaining paranasal sinuses, mastoid air cells, middle ear 
cavities are clear. IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process. 

5. CT CHEST: The thyroid gland appears normal. Scattered 
axillary and mediastinal lymph nodes do not meet CT criteria for

calcifications are seen within the coronary arteries and the 
thoracic aorta. The great vessels are normal in caliber. There 
is mild dependent atelectasis bilaterally. There are no nodules 
or 
masses detected. No pneumothorax is present. Diffuse osteopenia 
is seen. An impacted acute fracture of the left humeral neck 
(3:8, 1:2, 401:26) is better seen on the radiographic 
examination performed on the same day. Severe osteoarthritic 
changes including complete loss of the glenohumeral joint space,

to the

normal-appearing liver, spleen, gallbladder, adrenal glands, and

contains multiple punctate and coarse calcifications (2:55), 
likely reflecting the sequela of prior pancreatitis. IMPRESSION: 
1. Impacted left humeral neck fracture, also seen on the prior 
radiographic examination performed on the same day. Chronicity

presenting symptoms. 2. No rib fractures or pulmonary contusion. 
3. Mild displacement at the inferior portion of the sternum 
appears chronic as noted. Correlate with any tenderness within 
this region (400B:31) to rule 
out any superimposed acute process. 

6. CT NECK: There is no acute fracture or traumatic malalignment 
of the 
cervical spine. No prevertebral soft tissue abnormalities are 
detected.  
Severe multilevel degenerative changes are seen, including grade 
1 
anterolisthesis of C4 on C5 and C5 on C6, disc space narrowing,

sclerosis and cystic changes, and anterior and posterior

examination. The thyroid appears normal. Included views of the

anterolisthesis of C3 on C4, and C4 on C5, with overall

spine, 
unchanged in appearance since ___. There is 
mild-to-moderate spinal 
canal narrowing. If there is a high clinical concern for cord 
injury, MRI can be considered as a more sensitive test. NOTE 
ADDED AT ATTENDING REVIEW: There are bilateral fractures at C2. 
On the right this involves the lamina and extends into the 
inferior facet. On the left there is an isolated fracture of the 
C2 inferior facet, with no involvement of the lamina. These 
fractures are new since the ___, but the fracture lines 
do not appear as clear as would be expected for acute lesions.

this does not address the question of mechanical stability. This 
should be 
referred to Spine Surgery. An MR might be helpful to evaluate

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ lady with a h/o cocaine and IV heroin 
use who was transferred from an OSH due to MRSA sepsis from 
endocarditis complicated by lung abscesses.  She was in serious 
condition for much of her hospitalization, but she never 
decompensated into septic shock.  Her hospital course was 
notable for recurrent sinus tachycardia and fevers to 103, 
management of neutrophil-predominant pleural effusions s/p 
thoracenteses/chest tubes, brief MICU transfer for somnolence, 
and brief MICU transfer for hypoxia.  She improved slowly on 
Vancomycin IV.  When her chest tubes had been removed, and she 
was breathing comfortably on room air, and she became afebrile 
for >24H, she was discharged to rehab to complete her antibiotic 
course.

#. MRSA Sepsis: endocarditis with lung abscesses.
Fever to 103 with rigors, sinus tachycardia to 140, leukocytosis 
to 21K, and tachypnea all represented systemic response to her 
infection.  She grew MRSA from BCx at the OSH, but here the only 
(+) was the very first blood culture - all subsequent cultures 
were negative.  Though she had no murmur on exam, with MRSA 
bacteremia and continued fevers, clinically fits with 
endocarditis.  Most likely right-sided IE given that patient is 
IVDU, as well as the fact that she has lung emboli and no 
obvious left-sided peripheral emboli (head CT negative, MRI 
spine negative for abscess, CT abdomen negative for splenic 
abscess).  ___ TTE's did suggest a ?right-sided vegetation but 
this was not seen on subsequent TTE or TEE.  She continued to 
spike high fevers with infectious w/u negative for another 
cause, and these continued fevers were likely due to septic lung 
abscesses.  Effusions were managed with drainage (see below).  
She was followed closely by ID who recommended continuing 
Vancomycin, though she was changed to Daptomycin prior to 
discharge due to rash (see below).  Over time, she exhibited 
less septic physiology, and she became more comfortable.  Her 
leukocytosis resolved completely (WBC 5.4 on discharge).  She 
started to ambulate, breathing comfortably and was weaned to 
room air.  She stopped spiking fevers (last fever was 102.9 at 
2400 on ___, >2 days before discharge).  At this point, she was 
discharged to rehab to complete her treatment course; proposed 
end-day is ___ which will complete a 6-week course.  She 
should have weekly CBC, CHEM7, LFTs, and CPK faxed to ATTN: 
___ OPAT RNs at fax# ___.  She will follow-up in ___ 
clinic in 2.5 weeks (scheduled).  

#. Pleural effusions: neutrophil-predominant parapneumonic 
effusions, not empyema, slowly resolving.
Interventional Pulmonary was following.  She underwent the 
following procedures:
___ right thoracentesis
___ left chest tube insertion (removed)
___ left chest tube insertion (removed ___ right thoracentesis
The fluid was not consistent with empyema and likely represents 
inflammation due to her infection.  No growth from pleural fluid 
culture.  Based on imaging, the pleural effusion size has 
decreased.  In the future, if effusions do not resolve, she 
might require further procedures including possible pleurodesis. 
 She requires repeat CT chest in ~1 month to ensure that the 
effusions have resolved (scheduled); she also has follow-up 
scheduled at ___ Interventional Pulmonary clinic. 

#. Rash: likely from Vancomycin.
On the evening of ___ she was noted to have a mild thigh rash 
but by the next day she had erupted into a maculopapular 
blanching rash on her thighs, upper chest, back, and lower 
abdomen (arms were spared).  Also had a follicular-pattern rash 
on her legs.  No fever or leukocytosis.  Only mildly pruritic.  
No mucosal involvement.  It was felt that this likely 
represented a reaction to Vancomycin (even though it was started 
weeks prior).  Per I.D. recommendations, she was changed to 
Daptomycin, which she tolerated without complication.  

#. Somnolence requiring MICU transfer: resolved, likely a 
medication effect.
Patient was transferred to the ICU ___ due to being found 
very lethargic.  Review of her medications revealed several 
narcoticts and benzodiazepines that were suggestive of 
iatrogenic somnolence.  Opiods and benzodiazepines were held, 
with return of patient's baseline mental status.  Pain consult 
was performed who suggested no further IV pain medications, with 
use of Oxycodone instead.  She did not require Narcan and had no 
further episodes of somnolence.

#. Hypoxia requiring MICU transfer: resolved, likely from lung 
abscesses, effusions, fever.
Patient was transferred to the ICU ___ due to hypoxia (POx 
in the ___ on 4L NC).  Was likely related to her underlying 
lung infection and large effusions.  She underwent chest tube 
placement with some resolution.  Also, she might have had 
desaturation during fevers due to vasodilation and loss of 
hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to shunt physiology.  
She never required ventilatory assistance; she improved and was 
on 4L NC for much of her admission.  By the time of discharge, 
she was weaned to room air but was intermittently using O2 for 
comfort.

#. Pain control: complicated by her h/o IV heroin use and 
addiction.
Chronic Pain Service agreed that she is not a candidate for long 
term opioid therapy, but she did require some IV Dilaudid in the 
setting of chest tube placements and other procedures.  By the 
time of discharge, she was weaned to Oxycodone ___ PO Q4H 
PRN, and further down-titration and eventual cessation of 
narcotic pain meds would be appropriate while she is at rehab.  
She also continues on Tylenol, Lidocaine patch, and Gabapentin 
for pain control.  Had some mild dyspepsia with NSAIDs but these 
could certainly be used as well.  She would benefit from 
follow-up with an addiction specialist.

# Anemia: unclear etiology, resolved.
Hct was 29.6 on admission, had a nadir of 20.8 on ___, and was 
29.6 on discharge.  hemolysis/DIC workup negative and she was 
guaiac negative.  Likely from decreased RBC production and 
possibly from bleeding due to procedures.  She received a total 
of 6u pRBCs this admission.  Hct was stable at the time of 
discharge and she had no signs of bleeding.

#. Leg swelling: resolving.
She had symmetric leg edema and right ankle swelling, likely 
from requiring large volumes of IV fluids.  TTE showed good pump 
function.  LENIs were negative and ankle film showed no 
fracture.  With mobility and ambulation, the edema is resolving 
(currently trace edema upon discharge).

#. Psych: initial presentation with SI, but no SI this 
admission. 
She was closely followed by Social Work this admission.  She has 
expressed an interest in working on her mental health, mostly 
because she wishes to stay healthy for her son.  She never had 
any SI or HI while hospitalized here.  She should have follow-up 
with mental health providers after discharge.  She continues on 
Clonazepam.

#. h/o IV heroine use and cocaine use: patient wishes to stay 
drug-free.
She was tested for HIV, HCV, and HBV which were negative.  As 
mentioned above, she was followed closely by Social Work.  She 
did describe herself as a "heroin addict" and hopes to be able 
to stay drug-free after discharge.  She had no signs/symptoms of 
withdrawal this admission, but was treated with Clonidine 
initially (not continued upon discharge).  She should have 
follow-up with mental health providers after discharge.  

#. ?ADHD: was a pre-admission diagnosis.
She is prescribed Adderall extended release 30mg PO QAM and 
Adderall 30mg BID as an outpatient (confirmed with her 
pharmacy).  Unclear indication.  She requested to be restarted 
on Adderall and she was put on Adderall 10mg daily.  She should 
be encouraged to wean off amphetamine-based medication given her 
cocaine/heroin history.

#. Transitional Issues
-Code status: Full Code 
-Emergency Contact: mother ___ ___
-Access: PICC line placed ___
-***Please remove PICC line after antibiotic course is 
complete.***
-Pain control: By the time of discharge, she was weaned to 
Oxycodone ___ PO Q4H PRN, and further down-titration and 
eventual cessation of narcotic pain meds would be appropriate 
while she is at rehab, especially since her chest tubes were 
removed days ago.
-Fever: Last fever was 102.9 at 2400 on ___, >2 days before 
discharge.  If at rehab she spikes a fever >101, this would be 
an indication for repeat blood cultures, UA/urine culture, and 
chest x-ray.  If no source is found and fever persists, she 
should return to ___ for workup which could include chest CT

Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted the Trauma service. Neurosurgery and Orthopedics 
were consulted. He was taken to the Trauma ICU where his 
neurologic exam and serial head CT scans were followed and 
remained stable. He was started on Dilantin for seizure 
prophylaxis. He was taken to the operating room by Orthopedics 
for irrigation and debridement left iliac wing open fracture 
down to and inclusive of bone and open reduction internal 
fixation left iliac wing fracture with K-wires. There were no 
intraoperative complications. His scapula fracture was managed 
non operatively. Postoperatively he was taken back to the Trauma 
ICU where he remained for several days. 

He was later transferred to the regular nursing unit where he 
continued to progress. He did have pain control issues; the 
Acute Pain Service was consulted for epidural analgesia. An 
epidural catheter was placed and remained in for a couple of 
days and he was then changed to a long acting narcotic with 
shorter acting medications for breakthrough pain. 

For DVT prophylaxis he was started on Mini-Coumadin and will 
remain on this until fully ambulatory.

Physical therapy evaluation was done and worked with him on a 
regular basis; he made significant gains and was cleared for 
discharge to home. Follow up instructions were provided to 
patient.

Brief Hospital Course:

vertebral body: patient was evaluated in the ED by ortho spine 
at which point there was no indication for surgical 
intervention. MRI did not show evidence of cord compression. 
Ortho Spine reviewed films and thought fractures were chronic. 
C-collar was subsequently removed. There was question of a 
thoracic trachea protrusion on OSH read of CT scan which was 
reviewed by ___ thoracic CT radiology, and felt to be narrow 
AP diameter and no evidence of any endotracheal mass.  He 
underwent swallow and video swallow eval and deemed safe for 
ground solids and thin liquids under supervision.

# HCAP: CXR revealed a RLL infiltrate concerning for HCAP. In 
light of negative urine culture, hypoxia (2L NC O2 requirement) 
and fever, patient was treated with PO levoquin and will 
complete a 7 day course. 

# Urinary tract infection: febrile to 104 initially with a 
grossly positive UA.  Urine Cx was negative, however the patient 
received a dose of ceftriaxone prior to obtaining the culture. 
Completing treatment with levofloxacin. 

# Altered mental status: patient has baseline dementia, however 
mental status is acutely changed. Most likely delirium in the 
setting of urinary tract infection. LFTs, electrolytes, renal 
function and glucose are stable. CT head at OSH was w/o evidence 
of acute process. Improved but fluctuated throughout course.

# Atrial fibrillation with RVR: patient with known afib, 
currently on metoprolol PO at home. Not on anticoagulation given 
risk for hemorrhage. Patient had multiple episodes of RVR the 
first night of admission when he was not on home metoprolol. 
Episodes occured in the setting of agitation and fever. Patient 
was rate controlled with home dose metoprolol in-house and had 
no further episodes of RVR.

# Hypoxemia: patient has a new O2 requirement and required 2L O2 
at discharge without respiratory distress.  Patient underwent 
bilateral LENIs which did not reveal DVT. CTA was not performed 
due to low-risk for PE. On discharge patient's O2 requirement 
was 2L NC.  He is discharged with home O2 and would recommend 
evaluation for resolution of new O2 requirement in setting of 
pneumonia. Recommend weaning O2 as tolerated, and ___ CXR in 4 
weeks.  He was noted to have desaturations during sleep, raising 
suuspicion for OSA.  Would recommend polysomnogram and patient 
may cont to req O2 when sleeping.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with h/o esophageal and lung CA and SBO, CAD presents with 
1d of chest burning.

* Chest burning: Suspected GI etiology given her history. She 
was ruled out for MI. Chest CT demonstrated little to cause 
these symptoms. Gastroenterology was consulted and performed an 
EGD that showed duodenitis. This is likely the cause of her 
symptoms. A recurrencence of malignancy was not appreciated in 
the EGD. Her symptoms resolved during the hospitalization. She 
will be continued on high dose PPI BID and follow up with her 
PCP for further management. Biopsies of the gastrum were 
performed and were pending at time of discharge. H. pylori 
antibody testing was performed and the test at time of discharge 
was pending. Upon completion of this summary, the test returned 
as positive. She will need further work up in the outpatient by 
her PCP.

#Transaminitis: Patient noted to have a mild transaminitis which 
was trending down during her hospitalization to normal levels. 
Unclear etiology of this. Ultrasound was performed which showed 
no lesions that could address this. A repeat test should be 
considered in the outpatient setting.

# Lung Nodule: CT of chest showed significant interval 
enlargement of the right upper lobe nodule highly suspicious for 
lung cancer until proven otherwise. This worrisome finding is to 
be followed up in the outpatient. 

# Pharyngeal Polyps: Noted in EGD. Patient asymptomatic and is 
scheduled to follow up with ENT for further evaluation/removal 
in the outpatient setting. 

# Atypical Kidney Findings on CT: A heterogenous right kidney 
was reported on CT. The Chest CT did not capture the full kidney 
and this should be evaluated further in the outpatient. 

# CAD: Patient was ruled out for MI. Continued on asa, 
metoprolol and statin. 

# HTN: Stable, continued on metoprolol, amlodipine, and 
lisinopril.

# Glaucoma: Stable. Continued on home eye drops.

# Chronic Kidney Disease: Creatinine slightly above baseline 
during hospitalization. Slight elevation was thought to be due 
to poor po intake at home. Her home atenolol was changed to 
metoprolol during this hospitalization as this drug is cleared 
renally.

Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male who was found unresponsive 
and in asystole after a suspected suicide attempt by hanging s/p 
PEA arrest w/ resuscitation and ROSC currently intubated, 
sedated, and paralyzed undergoing targeted temperature 
management. History obtained from chart and family. 

Patient was found at home hanging from a tree. His wife, who is 
in an ICU nurse, cut him from the tree and started CPR. EMS 
found him to be in asystole and was immediately resuscitated 
with 1 round of epi and 2 minutes of chest compressions. He was 
brought to ___ where imaging showed fractures of ribs and 
manubrium along with a right proximal ICA dissection. He 
received mannitol at ___ per the wife, given presuming concern 
for cerebral edema. Lactate at ___ was 7.3, and urine drug 
screen was positive for etoh and fentanyl. He was transferred to 
___.

In our ED, initial vitals demonstrated sinus rhythm with HR ___ 
and normotensive. He was noted to be unresponsive with a GCS of 
3. He was started on targeted temperature management. He was 
also noted to have myoclonic movements and was given Ativan. 
This did not resolve the movements, so he was paralyzed with 
vecuronium.

Labs demonstrated WBC 23.5, Cr 1.2, Na 138, and Hgb 14.6. 
Initial blood gas 7.___ with lactate 3.1. Repeat VBG was 
7.20/34 with lactate 2.4. Serum tox was negative.

Vascular surgery was consulted and determined the patient had 
suffered a grade I vs II blunt cerebrovascular injury, and 
recommended starting a heparin drip at 15 U/kg. Trauma surgery 
was consulted and determined that the bony fractures were 
secondary to resuscitation and recommended MICU admission. 
Post-arrest team was consulted and recommended continuing arctic 
sun (goal 36C) to avoid fever, target pCO2 35-40, HOB 30 
degrees, and cvEEG. Patient remained intubated on CMV 500x18, 
PEEP 5, FiO2 40%.
