MRA brain w/ and w/o contrast ___:
4 mm aneurysm at the bifurcation of the left MCA is again noted
The T1 fat-sat axial imaging done through the right carotid bulb 
did not
demonstrate any hyperintensity to suggest intramural hematoma. 
The web-like
structure thus seen on CTA in the right carotid bulb most likely 
reflects a a carotid web, septated form of atherosclerotic 
disease, recanalized thrombus or chronic dissection.

MRA neck w/ and w/o contrast ___:
1. The web-like filling defect in the right carotid bulb is 
again noted. 
Please note that this area of concern was not included in the 
scan volume of the T1 fat-sat axial imaging.  This finding most 
likely suggests a web rather than dissection given the location 
and appearance.
2. Incidental finding of a 4 mm bulbous aneurysm arising from 
the bifurcation of the M1 segment of the left MCA.

MR cervical spine w/o contrast ___:
No acute spinal fracture or cord injury. Cervical spondylosis 
most marked at the C5-6 and C6-7 levels resulting in spinal 
canal narrowing as described above. Cervical spondylosis also 
results in multilevel neural foraminal narrowing as described 
above Web-like T2 isointense structure is again noted in the 
right carotid bulb. Please refer to MRA of the neck done ___ for a full description.

MRI Brain w/o contrast ___:
No acute intracranial infarct. No mass or hemorrhage. 4 mm 
bulbous outpouching at the bifurcation of the M1 segment of the 
left MCA
concerning for an aneurysm measuring 4 mm diameter. A couple of 
punctate periventricular and deep white matter T2 and FLAIR 
hyperintensities are nonspecific, but most likely represent 
sequela of microangiopathy.
Paranasal sinus opacification as described above.

CTA NECK ___:
1.  No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality. 
2.  Multiple left-sided rib fractures involving the anterior 
second through sixth ribs.  No pneumothorax. 
3.  Ground-glass opacities in the right apical and right lobe 
posterior 
segment suggestive of pulmonary contusion given recent chest 
trauma however aspiration and early pneumonia would be similar 
in appearance. 
4.  Hepatic steatosis. 

CT HEAD ___ READ:  
1. Oblique, linear filling defect at the right carotid bulb 
extending to the most proximal margin of the right internal 
carotid artery, without significant fat stranding or wall 
thickening possibly representing chronic dissection.  
Alternative is atheromatous septation disease of the right 
carotid bulb. Otherwise, patent neck vessels. 
2. Right greater than left upper lobe consolidation and 
ground-glass 
opacities, concerning for aspiration and possible superimposed 
infection. 
3. Possible filling defect in the left upper lobe pulmonary 
artery, 
incompletely evaluated on this exam.  A CTA of the chest would 
be recommended for further evaluation of possible pulmonary 
embolus. 

EEG ___:
This is an abnormal continuous ICU EEG monitoring study because 
of 
a slow and disorganized background. This finding suggests a 
mild/moderate 
nonspecific encephalopathy, likely related to hypoxic-ischemic 
injury. The 
most common other causes include, but are not limited to, 
medication effect, metabolic derangements and/or infection. 
There are no epileptiform discharges or electrographic seizures 
recorded in this study. Compared to the prior day's recording, 
there is no significant change.

#S/p Cardiac Arrest
EMS was called to home and patient was found in asystole after 
suicide attempt by hanging. Achieved ROSC after 1 round of epi 
and CPR. At ___ he was given mannitol for concern of cerebral 
edema, but re-read by radiology here showed less concern for 
edema. He underwent targeted temperature management then 
rewarmed for 72 hours as per protocol. Neurologic function 
improved significantly, and he was extubated on ___. He had 
subtle localizing defects on exam done by Neurology ___. 
Neurology followed and MR brain showed no evidence of anoxic 
injury or infarcts. At time of discharge patient returned to 
baseline prior to admission neurologic function.

# Rib fractures
b/l opacities (in setting of intubation) with leukocytosis and 
initial rising lactate concerning for community acquired 
pneumonia +/- aspiration pneumonia vs pneumonitis. He was 
started on Vanc/cefepime ___, Vanc was dc'd, and cefepime was 
completed ___nding ___.  Respiratory failure likely 
worsened by rib-fracture induced splinting and atelectasis, 
which was treated with acetaminophen, toradol, lidocaine patch, 
and incentive spirometer.   

# RIGHT CAROTID ARTERY VS. PLAQUE: There was initial concern for 
traumatic R carotid dissection based on imaging in the setting 
of hanging. Accordingly he was started on aspirin 81mg daily for 
3 months per vascular surgery recommendations. Later imaging did 
not show signs of dissection and the initial lesion is most 
likely a vascular web or ulcerated plaque. However, he is young 
with a minimal risk of bleeding and it was felt reasonable to 
continue aspirin for the planned 3 month course.

#Suicidal attempt: No known history of SI or attempts. The 
patient did not remember the events leading to hospitalization 
and was told of events on ___. He did not seem to fully 
process them. Psychiatry was consulted and recommended PRN 
Haldol, ramelteon for insomnia and 1:1 sitter. On reassessment 
psychiatry recommended inpatient admission to which he was 
agreeable.

pain, and possible PNA. There was also c/f alcohol withdrawal 
given tachycardia, fever, HTN above but he was not treated for 
this and per wife is not a heavy drinker. He was treated with

pain, and oxycodone ___ mg PRN Q4H breakthrough. Resolved on 
discharge from ICU.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo female admitted to the acute care 
trauma surgery service on ___own 4 stairs. 
Her past medical history is significant for alcoholism and 
heroin use. CT imaging showed a left mandibular fracture, a 
mildly displaced nasal bone, and a filling defect in the right 
external iliac vein. OMFS was consulted and recommended surgical 
repair. On ___ informed consent was obtained and she was 
taken to the OR for an open reduction internal fixation of left 
mandibular angle fracture and extraction of multiple teeth, 15, 
16, 18, 5, 30, 29, and 31. She was extubated and taken to the 
PACU until stable then transferred to the floor for further 
management. 

On POD 1 her diet was advanced to full liquids which she 
tolerated well and her pain was controlled with PO pain 
medications. An MRV confirmed a small nonocclusive, nonenhancing 
thrombus in the right external iliac vein. 
On POD 2 vascular surgery was consulted for the thrombus and 
recommended lower extremity non-invasive studies which were 
negative for DVT. 
On POD 3 a heparin drip was started.
On POD 4 coumadin therapy was initiated.

Case management and social work were involved in the patients 
care plan throughout the hospitalization. Her discharge plan was 
complicated by her need for anticoagulation and limited 
insurance coverage in ___. Several options were 
discussed with the patient such as returning to ___ to 
be followed by her primary care provider. She did not want to do 
that at this time. The decision was made with the patient to 
start Xarelto therapy since she would not have frequent blood 
draws. She was given a 2 week supply of medication from the care 
plus pharmacy. She plans to go back to ___ to see her 
primary care provider and further discuss treatment within the 
month. Her primary care was made aware of the plan and agreed to 
assist her in obtaining continued therapy. The risks associated 
with her diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis and anticoagulation 
treatment were discussed and the patient verbalized agreement 
and understanding with the plan. Please see case management note 
for further details.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a full 
liquid diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain 
was well controlled.  The patient was discharged and reports 
having a safe place to stay. The patient received discharge 
teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan. Follow up 
appointments were made.

Brief Hospital Course:
============================
BRIEF SUMMARY:
============================
___ is a ___ year old woman with PMH significant for 
two prior hemorrhagic strokes (patient now nonverbal and 
quadriplegic at baseline), HTN, epilepsy, COPD, Afib w/ RVR 
(CHADS-Vasc 6 - not on warfarin), and Sjogren syndrome who 
presented from her nursing home for evaluation regarding 
gastrostomy tube displacement, fixed on arrival, found to have 
evidence of LLL pneumonia.
============================
DETAILED SUMMARY BY PROBLEM: 
============================
# Pneumonia, unspecified organism ___ - Patient presented 
with findings including fevers, leukocytosis, and worsening L 
lower lobe effusion. Patient has recent echocardiography which 
shows mild pulmonary hypertension, but no evidence of left-sided 

CHF. Patient presents with risk factors included residence a 
nursing home, recent hospital admissions including an ICU course 

in ___ for sepsis ___ pneumonia. Unfortunately no known 
culture data was available but a negative MRSA swab was obtained 

in ___. Had prominent concerning features in history for 
aspiration, given hx of CVA. No hx of immunosuppression. In the 
emergency room chest x-ray demonstrated evidence of a left lower 

lobe question of atelectasis versus consolidation, deemed to be 
concerning for possible healthcare community-acquired pneumonia. 

Strep pneumo and legionella were negative. Blood cultures 
demonstrated one sample with GPCs in cluster, coagulase 
negative, deemed to be a likely contaminant. There was very low 
suspicion for endocarditis, hence a TTE was not performed during 

this admission. patient was treated with abx coverage initially 
with vancomycin, ceftazidime, Flagyl, thereafter transitioned to 

levofloxacin once GPCs in culture returned as 
coagulase-negative. On ___ patient experienced questionable 
event that was concerning for aspiration, not with any 
desaturations noted on O2 pulse oximetry, patient remained 
symptomatically at baseline and no repeat imaging or additional 
treatment was provided. Patient was treated symptomatically with 

DuoNeb's as per her standing orders for nursing home. There were 

several blood cultures pending at the time of discharge. She 
will continue an abx course with levofloxacin to complete 7 days 

worth of treatment (D1 = ___, D7 = ___.

# Abnormal electrocardiogram (R94.31) 
# Prolonged QT syndrome
Patient presented with new ECG findings including T wave 
inversions in leads V3-V6, and prolonged QT interval, compared 
with baseline in ___. It was difficult to assess patient 
symptoms. Patient received serial troponins x 3, which were 
negative. QTc prolonging medications (e.g. nausea, 
antipsychotics) were avoided.
# Unspecified atrial fibrillation I___ - Patient presented 
with CHADS-Vasc of 6 (points for age, gender, CVA hx, and HTN) - 

Stroke risk was deemed to be 9.7% per year in >90,000 patients 
(the ___ Atrial Fibrillation Cohort Study) and 13.6% risk of 

stroke/TIA/systemic embolism. She did not arrive on 
anticoagulation given family wishes, continued on patient on 
rate/rhythm control with metoprolol, verapamil (documentation 
provided by ___ home initially stated diltiazem, though this 

was clarified), presented with evidence of tachycardia. She was 
monitored on telemetry and not treated with anticoagulation. She 

received an infectious workup as above to assess for possible 
triggers for atrial fibrillation.

# s/p CVA w/ chronic seizures: patient minimally interactive at 
baseline. She was kept on fall/delirium precautions. Keppra was 
continued. Recommended regular changes in her position to 
protect against predisposition to sacral decubitus ulcer.

# HTN/CAD hx: Patient presenting with evidence of systolic 
blood pressures up to the 190s and 200s, dosing of 
antihypertensives provided on initial documentation from the 
nursing home was clarified. After clarification it became clear 
that diltiazem was no longer being prescribed, patient was now 
on verapamil. This was uptitrated over the course of 
hospitalization, with improved symptomatically controlled. 
Patient was no longer requiring as needed hydralazine at time of 

discharge. No current evidence of hypertensive emergency during 
admission, though difficult to assess exam ___ minimal 
interactivity. She was continued on her previous asa, 
furosemide, verapamil, and lisinopril w/ holding parameters.

NONACTIVE Issues:
# left ear bleeding - Per ED report patient had witnessed 
bleeding from the left ear, no known history of coagulopathy, 
not on atrial fibrillation anticoagulation. On evaluation on the 

floor there was visualized clotted blood within both ears (in 
the external canal), but no visualized focal bleeding around the 

TM on either side. No Battle's sign or other focal indications 
of head trauma. Patient received CT head which was reassuring 
with regard to possibility of traumatic head bleed. After stable 

exam the primary team stopped trending coags as exam was stable.

*Chronic Issues:
# Pain: Continued standing liquid APAP through G-tube without 
issue. Avoided narcotics given DNR/DNI and risk of sedation.

summary: You came in due to symptoms of lightheadedness and sweating, numbness and tingling. You have had testing done to make sure you were not having an acute injury to your heart and those were normal. Your heart rhythm was monitored overnight and there were no concerning abnormal rhythms seen. Your symptoms have not recurred. The most likely cause for this event was overactivity of the nerve that slow your heart rate but this occurs only transiently (vaso-vagal event). You may have these events recur in the future and if you do, please get to a sitting or laying down position to prevent from falling and hurting yourself.

shortness of breath. The patient developed URI symptomg 
including rhinitis, sore throat, cough on ___ and was 
prescribed a Z-pack. Initially she felt better, but rhinitis and 
cough persisted and developed sinus pressure. Cough is 
productive of thick yellow sputum and keeps her up at night. She 
has been using nebs ___ times per day. She saw her PCP ___ 
___ and was started on a prednisone taper with moxifloxacin 
for bronchitis/sinusitis, as well as Robitussin with codeine. 
She continues to have wheezing and cough. Peak flows at home 
have been around 350 with nl for her being 500-600. She denies

.

breath and voice hoarseness, initially treated as asthma though

and bronchoscopy that did not display TBM, though airway 
evaluation did disclose upper airway edema attributed to reflux 
with a question of vocal cord dysmotility (per outpatient

.

was started on Solumedrol 125mg IV and nebs on admission. Her

She was also given levo and Prednisone 50mg today.

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment and Plan: ___ year old female with a history of 
asthma, GERD, OSA p/w asthma exacerbation precipitated by URI.  
.  
# Asthma exacerbation/brochitis/sinusitis : The patient 
presented with an asthma exacerbation following 
bronchitis/sinusitis.  She did not have a fever, leukocytosis, 
or radiographic evidence of pneumonia.  She was treated with 
steroids, round the clock combivent nebs, high-dose inhaled 
fluticasone, and zileuton.  She was given 
dextromethorphan-guaifenisen for cough suppression.  She 
finished a 5 day course of levofloxacin for sinusitis.  She is 
discharged on a prednisone taper (10 mg less every 2 days) on 
albuterol/fluticasone inhalers and zileuton.  She has 
close-follow-up scheduled with her PCP.  She also has follow-up 
with her pulmonologist.
.
# Allergic rhinits:  The patient's allergic rhinitis was stable. 
 She is discharged on home mometasone nasal spray and 
Claritin-D.
.  
# Obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP: The patient's OSA as stable 
and she was maintained on CPAP.
.  
# GERD: The patient's GERD was stable.  She was maintained on 
ranitidine, omeprazole, and ursodiol.  It seems likely that she 
can tolerate discontinuing the ursodiol as an outpatient.

.

simple in
attenuation. The pleura appears is smooth but thikc; evaluation 
for infection
is limited without contrast.

collapse of the
right middle lobe.
3. Nodular consolidative opacity at the right apex raises the 
possibility of
an infectious process.
4. Enlarged thyroid. Consider outpatient thyroid function tests 
and
ultrasound if needed.
5. Atherosclerotic aortic and coronary artery calcifications.
6. Persistent cholelithiasis, atrophic kidneys and splenic 
calcifications.

chronic infarction MR is more sensitive in the detection of

with gadolinium is more sensitive in the detection of sequelae 
of intracranial

2. Small amount of fluid in the right maxillary sinus raises the

CT Head ___ w/o contrast:
1. No acute hemorrhage, mass effect, large mass, edema, or acute 
infarction is noted.  
2. Stable large region of cystic encephalomalacia and volume 
loss, consistent with remote right MCA territorial infarction. 
3. No pathologic enhancement. 
.
EEG ___:
This is an abnormal portable EEG due to slowing and 
disorganization of the background rhythm and intermittent focal 
slowing 
in the left frontal and anterior sylvian regions. These findings 

suggest a possible focus of subcortical dysfunction in this area 
and an 
underlying moderate to severe encephalopathy. Medications, 
toxic/metabolic disturbances and infections are common causes. 
There 
were no epileptiform discharges or electrographic seizures seen 
in this 
recording. 
.
CXR ___:
As compared to the previous radiograph, there is now complete 
opacification of the right hemithorax. The absence of 
mediastinal shift to 
the left suggests a combination of pleural effusion and 
atelectasis. The left lung shows unchanged apical thickening and 
a just minimal pleural effusion as well as a small retrocardiac 
atelectasis. Focal parenchymal opacity suggesting pneumonia are 
not present. The left-sided central venous access line has been 
removed in the interval 
.
CXR ___:
The endotracheal tube measures 4.4 cm above the 
carina. The right pleural effusion and partial collapse of the 
right lung are unchanged since ___. The cardiac 
and mediastinal silhouette is stable. The left lung is well 
expanded. There is no pneumothorax. The right-sided pacemaker 
and lead is unchanged in position. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
# Altered Mental Status: The patient was initially brought in to 
be evaluated for possible confusion per his family. However on 
further questioning, he initially appeared to be at his relative 
baseline (blind, nearly deaf, left hemiplegia, intermittently 
saying ___ words with signficant stimulation but rarely 
oriented). An RPR was found to be mildy positive and 
neurosyphyllis was thought to be possibly contributing to his 
confusion. To this end a lumbar puncture under fluoroscopic 
guidance was pursued. However, due to decompensation (see below) 
the LP was not completed. Given the risk of a repeat LP, under 
guidance from the infectious disease department, it was decided 
to treat him for presumed neurosyphyllis. He received 2 weeks of 
IV ceftriaxone, completed in house, with little improvement of 
his mental status after his arrest. After his arrest, the 
patients mental status became essentially unresponsive to any 
stimuli. Repeat CT head and EEG showed no acute process. The 
patient could not receive an MRI due to a pacemaker. In 
consultation with neurology, his new baseline may be a result of 
some anoxic brain injury.
.
# PEA arrest: The morning of his lumbar puncture, a CXR showed 
complete opacification of his right lung, likely indicating a 
significant mucous plug at that time. At baseline, he has a 
large, chronic, loculated pleural effusion that compresses most 
of the right lung, leaving only a small section aerated. During 
his lumbar puncture procedure, the patient suffered a PEA arrest 
and was down for approximately 5 minutes. He was resuscitated 
with CPR. As above, after the arrest, his mental status was 
essentially unresponsive. His ability to protect his airway was 
significantly decreased. After initial extubation after his 
arrest, he required frequent nasal trumpet suctioning to prevent 
recurrent mucous plugging. Even with frequent suctioning, he had 
several further mucous plugging events with significant 
desaturations requiring acute suction. The last such event was a 
near respiratory arrest on the general medical floor requiring 
re-intubation. After lengthy discussion with his family, it was 
decided to place a tracheostomy to attempt to minimize further 
mucous plugging events and ease suctioning, as he was having 
significant nasopharyngeal trauma from NT suctioning. Hyocamine 
tabs and mucomyst nebs were added to decrease and help clear 
secretions. He will require frequent suctioning and close 
monitoring of his airway to minimize further plugging events. 
The family was made aware that the tracheostomy may not prevent 
further events and that his overall mortality in the next year 
is significant. They feel strongly that the patient would want 
to continue living no matter what the cost. Extensive 
discussions were held regarding goals of care and code status 
with no change in his full code status. The family's overall 
goal is to bring the patient home if at all possible. 
.
# Respiratory Failure: As noted above, his last mucous plugging 
event resulted in reintubation. He is in the process of weening 
ventilatory support, currently on PS ventilation, ___, 40% with 
good respiratory mechanics. His ventilatory support should 
continue to be weened as tolerated with possible trach collar 
soon. Of note, given his poor right lung, it is unlikely that 
the patient will ever have a satisfactory RSBI. Sputum culture 
from ___ grew pseudomonas and pan-sensitive klebsiella. The 
patient had no evidence of actual pneumonia at that time. It was 
felt that the pseudomonas was likely a colonizer given that the 
exact same strain has been isolated from sputum cultures months 
prior. The klebsiella was concurrently treated during his 2 week 
course of ceftriaxone as above. Prior to discharge, a sputum 
culture was growing pseudomonas and one other gram negative rod. 
Again, he had no other clinical signs of pneumonia so new 
antibiotics were not started. Further follow of sputum culture 
should occur and if the patient decompensates, consideration of 
antibiotics treating pseudomonas should occur. 
.
# Pyuria: Patient had a grossly positive UA.  Ceftriaxone and 
vancomycin were given initially. Piperacillin-tazobactam was 
added and ceftriaxone discontinued when he became hypothermic 
and altered requiring ICU transfer. He was ultimately found to 
have a VRE urinary tract infection. He was treated with 
linezolid, with a recommended course of 7 days. .
.
# Hypothermia: On the first hospital day the patient's 
temperature dropped to <96 farenheit.  Other vital signs were 
stable.  Given concominant leukopenia and positive UA, this was 
concerning for sepsis.  Blood cultures were sent, and  warming 
blankets were placed.  The patient was transferred to the 
intensive care unit for closer monitoring in the setting of 
likely sepsis, his antibiotic regimen was broadened to 
vancomycin/zosyn. His hypothermia improved. He has been 
hypothermic on his last several admissions. It may be that his 
physiologic response to infection is hypothermia rather than 
hyperthermia, or he is an outlier at the lower extreme of 
temperature at baseline. On the floor after transfer out of the 
ICU he initially needed a bearhugger to maintain temperatures 
>96 and cultures done at that time were negative. He eventually 
was able to maintain temperatures ranging ___ without the 
assistance of a bear hugger. 
.  
#. ESRD:  Family reported episode of fistula bleeding the 
previous day.  Pressure dressing was in place on admission. Hct 
was decreased, possible secondary to this.  Transplant surgery 
initially evaluated the fistula and determined that it was 
functional and ready for use.  However, later on re-evaluation 
transplant surgery felt that his fistula needed revision prior 
to discharge. This was done and further hemodialysis should be 
avoided from his fistula for 2 weeks from ___. A tunnelled 
femoral HD line was placed for HD access until that time under 
___ guidance.
Dialysis was continued MWF schedule. Midodrine was added to help 
improve his BP prior to dialysis to assist with volume removal 
and to combat possible autonomic dysfunction given wide swings 
in blood pressure. 
.  
Enlarged Thyroid: He had chest imaging to evaluate pulmonary 
function. An incidential finding of thyromegaly was noted. TFTs 
are recommended as an outpatient. 
.
#. Hypernatremia:  This was likely secondary to hypovolemia and 
resolved.
.  
#. Coronary artery disease: Aspirin, and simvastatin were 
continued.
.  
#. Hypertension:  Lisinopril was continued.
.
#. Type II DM:  Oral hypoglycemics were initially held and ISS 
given, but restarted as his blood sugars became elevated. His 
lantus was increased from 12 U QHS to 16 U QHS with effect. 
.  
.  
#. Adrenal insufficiency- He is on 5mg prednisone daily at 
baseline. There was an initial concern for sepsis, thus he got 
high dose steroids,however ___ stim test was wnl. He was thus 
tapered, and returned to his home dose of 5mg daily prior to 
discharge. 
.
#. Access:  He has poor vasculature. Initial PICC was placed 
which was pulled back to midline prior to discharge as it was 
coming out a little.  
.
#. CODE STATUS: Full code  status was confirmed with the family.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were confused, and had also been having some vomiting, and bleeding from your fistula. You were found to have an infection of your urine which was treated with antibiotics. In the setting of working up your confusion, a lumbar puncture was attempted. During this you had low oxygen levels and your heart stopped. This was likely due to mucous plugging. To attempt to prevent further plugging events, a tracheostomy was performed. Your fistula was also surgically repaired and a tunnelled dialysis catheter was placed in your groin.

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the Vascular Surgery ward a day prior to 
scheduled right lower extremity angiogram. On admission, 
preoperative labs were obtained and patient kept NPO starting at 
midnight with adequate intravenous hydration. The following 
morning he was taken to the angiogram suite prior discussion of 
risks and benefits of the planned procedure, which the patient 
and health-care proxy consented to proceed with. He underwent 
RLE angiogram and findings included stenosis of right external 
iliac artery like a shelf, 2 vessel run-off (___) with distal 
DP reconstitution (AT w/ multiple stenoses ___. Given 
findings, percutaneous transluminal angioplasty was done with an 
8 mm balloon to the right external iliac artery (please see 
Operative Note for further details). Patient tolerated the 
procedure well and was transferred back to the floor after a 
brief uneventful stay in the PACU.

Patient remained alert and oriented throughout hospitalization. 
His pain was under control. He was started on a regular diet 
upon return to the floor, which was well-tolerated. All home 
medications were resumed and patient was started on plavix. 
Given appropriate response, decision was made to discharge back 
to nursing facility where he came from. Discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions were discussed with patient and explained 
in detail in paperwork, with verbalized understanding and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

changes, consider infarction in the appropriate clinical 
setting.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with hypertension and diabetes who is admitted after being 
discharged on ___ after resection of craniopharyngioma on ___ 
with central diabetes insipidus and headache.

# Central diabetes insipidus: The patient has central diabetes 
insipidus manifesting with hypernatremia, polyuria and 
substantial thirst in the post-neurosurgical setting. The 
patient had been managed with PO demospressin on discharge. 
There was concern that the patient had taken her desmopressin 
with food after discharge, which may have interfered with the 
drug's absorption and led to her hypernatremia. 

The patient was initially given D5W IV with good response in her 
sodium level. Endocrinology was consulted. The patient was 
initially monitored with q4 hour serum sodium and urine specific 
gravity/osmolality checks. A foley was placed and urine output 
was monitored hourly. The patient was initially dosed with 
desmopressin when she would "break through" with >300cc of urine 
output per hour for two consecutive hours. Her desmopressin 
dosing was gradually stabilized to 0.2mg QHS, with strict 
instructions to not take with food. The patient was strongly 
encouraged to drink to thirst. Her labs were spaced out to twice 
daily. She still had occasional morning hypernatremia that was 
likely a consequence of the patient not drinking fluids 
overnight. When the patient was stabilized her foley was removed 
to reduce infection risk.

The patient was discharged to rehab on 0.1mg desmopressin BID at 
7am and 9pm. She was discharged with a ___ appointment in 
place with her endocrinologist.

# Headache: The patient had a headache on admission and 
occasionally throughout the admission. There was initially 
concern for post-operative hematoma. She had a head CT scan 
which was not concerning to her neurosurgeons. Her headache 
improved with Tylenol and tramadol. Her neurologic exam was 
unchanged.

# Bilateral Eye pain/episcleritis: On ___ the patient 
developed bilateral eye pain with her headaches. Her eyes  were 
tender to the touch. Ophthalmology saw the patient. They 
diagnosed her with episcleritis. Her pressure in the eyes were < 
12 and <10 in the R and L respectively, which was not concerning 
for glaucoma. She was treated with artificial tears and 
tobramycin-dexamethasone drops with improvement of her eye pain. 
 Of note, the patient had poor visual fields and acuity during 
this admission, which per ophtho is her baseline. She was 
discharged with a ___ appointment with ophthalmology.
- continue tobramycin-dexamethasone 0.3 %-0.1 % 1 drop OPH: 
Three times a day from ___

#Acute kidney injury: the patient had a creatinine bump to 1.3 
on ___, up fro her baseline of 0.9. This was likely from 
increased urine output and relatively poor PO intake. On 
discharge creatinine and BUN has decreased.  

#Anemia: the patient had hemoglobins in the ___ range during 
this admission. She had no obvious source of bleeding. Regular 
blood draws may have been contributing.

#Thrombocytopenia: Pt developed a thrombocytopenia on ___ that 
has been slowly downtrending. Today pt 107. Its unlikely to be 
infectious given afebrile, normal WBC count and no indication of 
infectious source. Still can be medication, acetamenophen is a 
common cause of thrombocytopenia and in <1% of cases Keppra can 
cause bone marrow suppression with thrombocytopenia. Broader 
differential is increased destruction or decreased production. 
Could be MAHA (DIC, HUS, TTP), since there is also an anemia. 
Had blood smear with 1+ rouleaux formation on peripheral smear; 
should follow up with PCP for further workup as indicated

# Craniopharyngioma. The patient had her brain tumor resected on 
her prior admission. During this admission we continued her 
pituitary hormone replacement regimen as per endocrinology. In 
addition to her desmopressin as above, we continued 
lenothyroxine, prednisone, and keppra prophylaxis.

# Diabetes: chronic. The patient was given an insulin sliding 
scale during this admission with good control of her blood 
sugars. 

# Left toe pain: Pt has about a week of tow pain on left toe, 
possibly with joint involvement. Tender to palpation, not 
erythematous, hard to tell whether it is warm to palpation due 
to warm compress. Could be gout, but unlikely infectious. 
- Continue to use warm compress
- Increased dose of acetaminophen 

***TRANSITIONAL ISSUES***

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female admitted to Acute Care Surgery Service after 
a fall down stairs while intoxicated resulting in a Grade 3 
liver laceration, perinephric hematoma, right ___ rib fx, 
right humerus close fx (s/p reduction). Upon admission, the 
patient was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, and underwent 
imaging.  

Serial hematocrits were monitored for the liver laceration and 
were stable at low ___. The patient's lactate and CK were also 
trended and were coming down. Because of the patient's injuries, 
the Orthopedic service was consulted and the  patient underwent 
a closed right humerus s/p reduction.  Her activity orders 
include: NWB, ROMAT at elbow + shoulder in ___.  The 
patient also sustained  ___ right rib fractures.  Her pain has 
been controlled with oral analgesia.  

During the patient's hospitalization, she experienced difficulty 
voiding and had a foley catheter replaced twice for urinary 
retention. She was started on a course of  Flomax and a second 
attempt at foley removal was successful.  She has been voiding 
without difficulty. She was started on a 7 day course of 
ciprofloxacin for a klebsiella UTI.   The patient was evaluated 
by the Psychiatry service for depression and recommendations 
were made for admission to an in-patient psychiatric facility to 
further manage her depressive symptoms and  
psychosis.

The patient has been medically cleared for discharge to an 
inpatient psychiatric facility

Brief Hospital Course:
Thrombophlebitis: Despite an extensive work-up, no specific 
focus of infection was identified. This was partly confounded by 
the initiation of antibiotics early in her hospitalization, but 
even the culture data obtained prior to antiobiotic therapy 
remained negative. MRI/MRA of the left arm and shoulder were 
read as "dilated and thrombosed left cephalic vein throughout 
its visualized course, with extensive surrounding edema 
suggesting thrombophlebitis." 

Transplant surgery attempted a thrombectomy, but was 
unsuccessful. They did not feel that there was evidence of 
infection in or around the thrombus and felt that her fevers 
were likely related to her significant clot burden. They 
recommended discontinuation of antibiotics and not starting 
anticoagulation. 

We explained the warning signs of infection and asked that she 
follow her symptoms closely and call or return if she develops 
fevers, swelling or pain.

W/MEALS (3 TIMES A DAY WITH MEALS).

hours) as needed for pain, fever: do not take more than 3500mg

(6) hours as needed for pain for 7 days.

* Hypertension in the past, though no anti-hypertention 
currently due to hypotension  
* Sjogren syndrome  

 
Discharge Condition:
afebrile, stable vitals, tolerating POs, ambulatory
summary: You were admitted for a fever after hemodialysis and pain with your AV fistula. You were treated for a probable line infection and for an infection of your AV fistula clot (thrombophlebitis) with antibiotics called daptomycin and gentamicin, which you tolerated well without reaction. You also had an MRI of left shoulder/arm due to pain and the AV fistula infection, which showed findings consistent with inflammation of the clot in the AV fistula (thrombophlebitis). Transplant surgery was consulted but did not recommend any surgery initially but then recommended removal of the AV fistula clot (thrombectomy), however, they could not succesfully remove your AV fistula clot since it was too large in its extension. After the surgery there were no other further recommendations for treatment of this clot since the clot was not infected and was in a superficial area (as opposed to a deep area). You also had your regularly scheduled hemodialysis on ___ and ___. You should attend your next dialysis as normally scheduled on ___ (___). You will not require any antibiotics, anticoagulation or other medicines for your clot. There are no new changes to your medications.

.
# CT chest ___:
1. Well marginated 3.5 cm mass abutting the pleura in the 
posterior segment of the right upper lobe corresponding with the 
region of abnormality seen on the previous chest radiograph. 
Further characterization with PET CT is recommended to exclude 
malignancy. If no FDG activity is seen within this lesion on PET 
imaging, a followup chest CT is recommended in three months to 
assess for temporal stability.
2. Bilateral small pleural effusions with adjacent relaxation 
atelectasis.
3. Calcified mediastinal lymph nodes suggesting previous 
granulomatous infection.
4. Moderately severe compression fractures of several mid 
thoracic vertebral bodies of unknown chronicity. Recommend 
correlation with outside imaging studies to assess stability.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ ___ speaking h/o HTN, hyperlipidemia, prostate cancer, 
admitted to the MICU with CAP and sepsis, and found to have a 
mass in right lung apex.  
.  
# Community acquired pneumonia/sepsis:  Given patient's 
admission x-ray, community acquired pneumonia was considered the 
most likely cause for his symptoms and hypotension.  Blood and 
urine cultures were negative.  Patient was begun on a 10 day 
course of levofloxacin and was discharged with good ambulatory 
oxygen saturations on room air.
.  
# Acute renal failure: Patient was in acute renal failure with 
elevated creatinine of 2.3 on admission.  He received IV fluids 
and antibiotics for septic pneumonia, and his creatinine 
returned to baseline.
.  
# Falls: Patient's falls were considered likely secondary to 
infection and sepsis.  CT head on admission was negative for 
ICH, and he received physical therapy while inpatient.
.  
# Hypertension: Patient presented with hypotension, and his home 
regimen of antihypertensives were initially held.  On transfer 
to the floor he was borderline hypertensive and outpatient 
antihypertensive regimen resumed including nifedipine.  Atenolol 
stopped and he was changed to metoprolol given acute renal 
failure on admission.  
.
# Lung mass NOS: CXR on admission revealed a rounded nodule at 
right apex concerning for malignancy.  CT chest demonstrated a 
3.5 cm mass abutting pleura in posterior segment of RUL.  
Radiology recommending characterization with PET CT.  the 
patient was provided with a PET CT appointment and given 
instructions on preparing for the exam.  Follow-up was arranged 
as an outpatient.  
.  
# Prostate cancer: Patient's history of known prostate cancer 
was considered a possible source of his new lung mass.  Patient 
was continued on doxazosin, with PSA less than 0.1.
.  
# Full code

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of chronic 
depression and HCV cirrhosis status post orthotopic liver 
transplant, who presented for evaluation of altered mental 
status and suicidal ideation after recently initiating 
venlafaxine.  

## Bipolar NOS (bipolar I or II vs med-induced): 
On admission, his mental status exam was notable for agitated 
behavior, rapid, almost pressured speech, irritable mood, 
endorsements of suicidal ideation, and poor insight/judgment, 
and delusional/psychotic thoughts.  The history and exam was 
suggestive of hypomania, but further evaluation for medical 
causes of alterred mental status were pursued given his history 
of immunosuppresion in the setting of liver transplant.  The 
patient endorsed marijuana use, but denied any other illicit 
drug use and his tox screens were negative.  There was initially 
a concern for tacrolimus toxicity given his elevated level to 
17.1 on ___, although this was felt to be an inaccurate 
trough level as his repeat tacrolimus level was 3.5. No 
meningeal signs on exam to suggest meningitis. Extensive 
infectious workup was unrevealing (negative urinalysis, negative 
CXR, RPR negative, HIV negative, CMV viral load undetected, lyme 
negative, EBV tested in the past c/w previous infection, HSV ___ 
positive).  While HSV was positive, MRI of the brain was largely 
unremarkable and neurological exam was unremarkable. EEG was 
entirely normal. Metabolic workup, including TSH was also 
unrevealing.  

On admission, venlafaxine was discontinued.  The patient's home 
cyclobenzaprine, mirtazapine, and gabapentin were also held as 
they can contribute to AMS.  Tacrolimus was initially held as 
well, but was restarted after the repeat tacrolimus level of 3.5 
and normal MRI of the brain.  Psychiatry was consulted, who felt 
his alterred mental status was likely Bipolar NOS (bipolar I or 
II vs med-induced).  The patient was started on olanzapine 5mg 
PO BID.  He was also given Ativan 0.5mg PO for anxiety.  He was 
placed on a 1:1 sitter.  The patient was medically cleared for 
psychiatric admission.    

## Status post orthotopic liver transplant: 
The patient had no evidence of decompensation of donor liver on 
admission.  His liver function tests were largely unremarkable.  
He had no evidence of hepatic encephalopathy or ascites on exam. 
 Tacrolimus intially held because it was elevated at 17.4 on 
___, although this was felt to be an inaccurate trough 
level as his repeat tacrolimus level was 3.5.  Tacrolimus was 
restarted at his home dose of 2mg Q12H.  He was discharged at a 
therapeutic level.  He was continued on his home dose of 
mycophenolate and ursodiol.  Dapsone was held since he is more 
than ___ year status post liver transplant.  

## Hepatic artery stenosis s/p stent placement ___:  
During his hospitalization, he was continued clopidogrel and 
aspirin.  

## Hypertension:
During his hospitalization, he was continued on his home 
Metoprolol Tartrate and Amlodipine, with adequate blood pressure 
control.

Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT: 
___ is a ___ year old female with a history of asthma, 
emphysema, CV disease, high BP, high cholesterol, NIDDM, R 
breast cancer, who presents with chest pain concerning for 
possible unstable angina, as well as shortness of breath.  After 
her ED course, pain resolved and feelings of acute shortness of 
breath resolved, however low O2 saturations in the ED on 
exertion to 79% were concerning, and patient was admitted for 
further work up.
.
PLAN:  
*Chest pain: Patient presented with acute onset of chest 
pressure, jaw pain and arm pain. Although she generally has 
about ___ episodes a week that are relieved by nitroglycerin, 
this episode was notable for no decrease in pain with treatment. 
Additionally, the specific symptoms of jaw pain and chest 
pressure are not present with her usual episodes of chest pain. 
Her labs are notable for negative troponin, that was trended and 
remained negative.  Stress test showed no anginal symptoms or 
ischemic ST segment changes.  Nuclear stress test was performed 
as well which showed no new changes in heart function or 
perfusion.  Given the lack of F/C, time course of chest pain, 
and symptoms, suspect that her chest pain symptoms were not 
attributable to flow-limiting coronary disease.  She did not 
have a recurrence of pain, and her vital signs and telemetry 
were monitored and stable throughout admission.  She will follow 
up with her PCP for further management.    
.  
*Shortness of breath: Patient noted shortness of breath on 
admission.  Her D-Dimer in the ED was negative, given her low 
Well's criteria score, and low clinical suspicion, no additional 
tests for PE were performed as this effectively r/o 
thromboembolic process.  No recent history of URI, so less 
likely to be infectious. Given the timing of SOB coinciding with 
chest pain, likely cardiac or COPD exacerbation. On the floor, 
O2 sat have been recorded in ___ without O2. Prior to discharge, 
it was determined that with exertion, O2 min on RA --> 83, O2 
min on 1L --> 88, O2 min on 2L --> 90. ABG showed pH of 7.39, 
pO2 of 72, pCO2 of 42. Likely due to chronic COPD.  Pulmonology 
saw her and thought this is most likely due to her long-standing 
COPD that has likely been chronic, and that this hypoxia is most 
likely not a new event. They recommended an ECHO with bubble 
study to rule out right to left shunting as an outpatient and 
recommended home O2.  On day of discharge, patient was 
comfortable, 96% on 2L O2, without chest pain or shortness of 
breath.   
.  
*Anemia: patient has anemia on CBC with most recent Hct of 31.7. 
This appears to be non-acute and did not down trend while 
admitted.  Continued home B12 supplement, and continue to 
monitor on outpatient basis.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with HgbSS disease, recurrent 
vasoocclusive crises, history of priapism, chronic hep C (viral 
load undetectable at ___ in ___ and polysubstance abuse who 
presented to ___ with acute onset low back pain consistent 
with vasoocclusive crisis. 

Active diagnoses:
#Vasoocclusive crises: He was admitted for a 1 day history of 
severe lower back pain in the setting of a Hemoglobin SS disease 
(sickle cell disease). Smear was suggestive of active sickling 
and hemolysis making the cause of his pain likely an acute pain 
crisis. Pain was limited to the R paraspinal area of the lumbar 
spine and there was no evidence of midline lumbar spine 
involvement (no tenderness to palpation). There was no evidence 
of priapism (he has a prior Hx of priapism).  Treatment 
consisted of pain control and IVFs with ___ normal saline. Pain 
was adequately controlled per the patient and by HD#2 and the 
pain had returned to his baseline. He was actually treated with 
less than his home regimen of oxycodone. He also received 1 u 
pRBCs on HD #1 which likely contributed to his improvement. His 
hemoglobin at discharge was 7.5. This is within his historical 
range for hemoglobin at discharge from ___ in the 
past few months. He should have a follow up CBC on ___ in 
___ clinic. Home folate and hydroxyurea were continued.   
   

#Hypoxemia: In the late morning on hospital day #1 he was found 
to have O2 sats to the mid-80s on room air. His saturation 
quickly improved to >95% on 2L of O2. On further auscultation he 
appeared to have decreased breath sounds and dullness to 
percussion at the R lung base. However, a CXR was done and no 
major consolidation was noted.  The etiology of his hypoxemia 
remains unclear, though it was most likely related to 
hypoventilation as he was very somnolent on hospital day #1. 
Acute chest crisis (ACS) was unlikely given his normal CXR and 
lack of chest pain or shortness of breath. On the day of 
discharge he was 94% on room air and his lungs were clear on 
examination.

#Hemoglobin SS disease/Macrocytic Anemia: On initial 
presentation to the ED (___) his Hct was 23.3.  The following 
morning (___), his Hct was noted to have dropped to 20.8, 
though after significant IV fluid. His anemia was likely due to 
a hemolysis from sickle cell disease, as confirmed by labs and 
peripheral smear. His bilirubin was elevated (6.4. total), 
haptoglobin level decreased (<5), LDH elevated (612) and 
reticulocyte was increased (12.8), as expected with a hemolytic 
anemia. He was transfused with 1 unit of pRBCs. On repeat Hct he 
was 23.1. He should have outpatient CBC done on ___ in 
___ clinic. 

#Somnolence: Upon admission to the floor (HD #1) he was noted to 
have significant somnolence, often appearing to doze off during 
history taking and physical exam.  This was thought to be due to 
overmedicating with pain medications and so his oxycodone and 
hydromorphone doses were reduced. It was also thought that he 
may have ingested other substances prior to admission, including 
long acting oxycodone, which he has at home. He has a history of 
substance abuse and was noted to have ingested cocaine this 
weekend. Tox screening from the ED was negative though it did 
not test for opiates and is unreliable for certain 
benzodiazepines. He did not produce a urine sample for testing 
for methadone and other CNS depressants. Given his return to 
normal mental status on HD#2 it is highly likely that his period 
of AMS was due to overmedication. He was counseled to avoid 
excessive narcotic use and combinations with other drugs. He was 
prescribed a bowel regimen given his chronic opiate use. 

Chronic Diagnoses: 
#Chronic Hepatitis C: Possibly resolved. Hep C antibody positive 
___. Viral load negative at ___ in ___, though 
it is unclear if he was treated or cleared the infection 
himself. This is related to blood transfusions for Sickle Cell 
Disease, per patient and chart review. He denies prior IV drug 
use. Could consider repeating viral load or clarifying treatment 
with patient to ensure no longer has active disease that would 
require treatment. 

#Polysubstance abuse: He reported that he had used cocaine a day 
or two prior to admission - this is an issue that his outpatient 
hematologist has spoken with him about before and which will 
need further outpatient workup as it is likely an exacerbating 
factor for his underlying sickle cell disease. He was counseled 
to avoid excessive narcotic use and combinations with other 
drugs. He was prescribed a bowel regimen given his chronic 
opiate use.

summary: You were admitted to ___ after sustaining an injury that resulted in a left sided pneumothorax. What is a collapsed lung? A collapsed lung, also called a pneumothorax, happens when air enters the space between your rib cage and one of your lungs. The air causes all or part of the lung to collapse. It is then hard to breathe normally and your body gets less oxygen. A collapsed lung can be life-threatening. In some cases, the air collecting around the lung can completely collapse the lung and put pressure on the heart. Then the heart cannot pump normally. A collapsed lung may be caused by an injury to the chest, such as a car accident, stab or bullet wound, or broken ribs. It may also be caused by lung damage from chronic lung diseases, electric shock, or near drowning. Sometimes there is no known cause for the lung to collapse. This is called a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of Hepatitis 
C/alcoholic cirrhosis and metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. 
He is currently on home hospice. He was admitted with increased 
fatigue and found to be in acute renal failure with 
hyperkalemia.

# Goals of Care: Mr. ___ was at home with hospice care. 
However, he initially received aggressive medical management of 
his hyperkalemia and acute renal failure. During the day after 
admission he met with palliative care to clarify his goals of 
care. He stated that prior to admission he was very anxious 
about his eventual death. He felt as though he had no resources 
through hospice to help make him feel better. He stated that he 
wanted to feel better when he was awake to make the most out of 
the remainder of his life. Certain medication changes were made 
such as minimizing pills because he did not like to swallow them 
and adding an anxiolytic. Communication between hospice and Mr. 
___ was facilitated so that he could achieve his goals at 
home. Social work was also scheduled to see him at home. Mr. 
___ wished to leave the hospital prior to full resolution 
of his acute renal failure and hyperkalemia.
.
#Hepatic Encephalopathy: Reportedly, he had been somewhat 
confused at home. He was given lactulose on admission. The 
morning after admission he was A&Ox3. There was no evidence of 
SBP, so the antibiotic treatment started in the ED was not 
continued.
.  
#Hyperkalemia: He had hyperkalemia with peaked T waves. He was 
aggressively treated in the emergency department with calcium 
gluconate, bicarbonate, insulin, and glucose. On the floor he 
was given kayexalate. His spironolactone was held. 
.  
# Acute Renal Failure: His spironolactone was held. He was given 
IV fluids and PO was encouraged. His renal failure was thought 
to be related to decreased PO intake.
.  
# Anemia: His iron pills were stopped because they were not 
consistent with his goals of care.   
.  
# HCV/EtOH cirrhosis: Continued lactulose and rifaximin for 
comfort and prevention of hepatic encephalopathy. 
.  
# Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Continued current regimen.  
.  
# GERD. Continued PPI.  
.  
# Depression. Continued wellbutrin.  
.

summary: You were admitted to the hospital with confusion and sleepiness. These were atributed to hepatic encephalopathy (brain disease caused by liver failure and ammonia). We gave you lactulose which improved your mental status. You should continue to take lactulose at home, since this medication helped to clear the ammonia. You were also noted to have an elevated potassium. You should not continue to take spironolactone, since this medication raises the potassium level. You can continue to take lasix to prevent fluid accumulation. You told us that your goals of care continue to be towards maximizing comfort.

# Abnormal CT scan (___): CT chest significant for worsening 
of chronic bronchogenic infection involving all the basal 
segments of the lower lobe, much of the right middle lobe, and 
even some of the right upper lobe. Concerning for all 
mycobacterial species including tuberculosis, though patient has 
no TB risk factors. ___ CXR showed persistent right greater 
than left basilar regions of consolidation. X-ray evidence of 
pneumonia dates back to CXR on ___. ED sputum cultures 
positive for gram positive rods found to be growing proteus and 
budding yeast. Patient with occasional chills, night sweats, and 
dyspnea on exertion for the past 3 weeks and mild cough 
productive of yellow-green sputum 1 month ago, but no fevers and 
no cough currently. Induced sputum was obtained for acid-fast 
staining and three sputums were negative, ruling out for active 
tuberculosis. She was started on treatement for CAP and received 
levoquin x1 day, ceftriaxone x3 days, and then was transitioned 
to augmentin for a 14 day course to start on ___ and complete 
___ for treatment of chronic aspiration. She was given 
azithromycin from ___. Pulmonology was consulted and 
thought the chronicity of her lung findings may be consistent 
with chronic aspiration. A speech and swallow eval was performed 
and showed no concern for aspiration. Immunoglobin levels were 
checked and showed elevate IgG and IgM. HIV was negative. 
Pulmonary recommended follow up in 6 weeks with a repeat CT scan 
at that time. Her respiratory status remained stable during her 
admission.

# Neck pain: Patient complains of 1 month of severe, stabbing 
cervical neck pain that radiates down her right arm and is 
exacerbated by turning her head. Moderate tenderness to 
palpation of and crepitus in ~T5 spinous process on exam. ___ 
CT cervical spine showed facet joint hypertrophy, subchondral 
cystic change, and a small joint effusion at the right C2-3 
facet joint likely due to degenerative change. Statistically and 
based on radiographic evidence, most likely cervical 
osteoarthritis. Pain was controlled with acetaminophen, 
oxycodone, gabapentin, and lorazepam.

# Cirrhosis: Patient with history of Child B cirrhosis (MELD 
score 8 on admission) secondary to chronic Hepatitis C infection 
c/b ascites, grade II esophageal varices seen on EGD in ___, 
and HCC. She was continued on home doses of torsemide, 
spironolactone, and nadolol. An EGD was performed that showed 3 
cords of grade I varices were seen in the lower third of the 
esophagus.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F who presented to the Emergency 
department as a transfer from outside hospital after sustaining 
a motor vehicle crash. She underwent CT head, chest, and torso 
that showed a C2 transverse foramen fracture, sternal fracture, 
and mediastinal hematoma. Neurosurgery was consulted and 
recommended CTA to rule out vascular injury and there was none. 
The patient was maintained in a hard cervical collar and 
admitted to the floor on continuous telemetry monitoring for 
pain control and hemodynamic monitoring.

The patient underwent tertiary survey that was negative for any 
further injuries. Pain was controlled on oral medications. She 
had no cardiac events on continuous telemetry monitoring. Diet 
was tolerated without difficulty. During this hospitalization, 
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with a history of paroxysmal afib s/p TEE/PVI 
on ___ who presents with chest pain, found to be in atrial 
fibrillation with RVR at PCP's office, now in sinus rhythm 
admitted for cardiac catheterization.
  
# Atrial fibrillation with RVR: Pt presented with afibw tih 
RVR,a dn was palced on diltiazem drip in the ED with resolution 
of rapid ventricular response. When patient arrived to the 
medicine floor, patient was hemodynamically stable with normal 
heart rate. She intermittently flipped into atrial fibrillation 
despite a recent PVI and propafenone. CHADS2 score is 0. 
Patient's dabigatran was held for cath and resumed therafter. Pt 
was resumed on cardizem xr 240, which she had previously been 
taking prior to PVI. 
.
# Cardiac cath: Per d/w attending cardiologist, pt had negative 
stress test ___ yrs ago. There is no known evidence of CAD. 
However, pt is unable to do exercise stress test, and dobutamine 
is contraindicated in afib with RVR, and MIBI would be poor 
quality given body habitus. There was concern for ischemic 
etiology leading to afib. Troponins were 0.05 x2. TIMI score was 
at most 13% of poor outcome in 14 days. Pt described chest pain 
twice over preceeding 2 days, once at rest and other while 
walking. Thus, there was concern that chest pain could be from 
CAD in setting of afib wth RVR leading to demand ischemia. 
Cardiac cath was performed and was ultimately negative for CAD.  

 
# Asthma/COPD: Chronic.  Pt was continued on symbicort, 
montelukast, fluticasone. 

# Sleep Apnea: Patient was continued on CPAP (brought in from 
home)  

# GERD: Chronic.  PAtient was continued on pantoprazole  

# Hypothyroidism s/p thyroidectomy: Chronic. Patient was 
continued on levothyroxine  

# Constipation: Pt was continued on docusate sodium

Your cardiologist was concerned that your atrial fibrillation could be related to your having coronary artery disease, so you underwent a procedure in which we looked at your coronary arteries (called cardiac catheterization). effusion is likely.  No pneumothorax.  Right jugular line ends 
in the upper SVC.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ y/o M h/o advanced dementia with 
chronic urinary catheter in place with hx in ___ of coagulase 
negative staph bacteremia on suppressive Bactrim presenting from 
home with diarrhea, lethargy, decreased responsiveness, found to 
have fungal and streptococcus anginosus septic shock likely ___ 
multifocal aspiration pneumonia requiring pressors and IVF, with 
stable blood pressures and improvement in clinical status now 
discharged from MICU to floor. Patient is CPR/Intubation not 
indicated - confirmed by two attending physicians and documented 
in Metavision.

#Septic and Hypovolemic Shock ___ bacteremia/fungemia:
Patient w/poor PO intake and chronic aspiration prior to 
admission to MICU. Extensive microbiologic workup negative for 
legionella, C. diff. Found on imaging to have a multifocal 
pneumonia in setting of aspiration given daughter's ___ 
feeding with regular diet and septicemia with streptococcus, 
lactobacillus, and C. albicans. Initially patient was treated 
with Vancomycin/Zosyn which after consultation with the 
infectious disease team was transitioned to ceftriaxone, 
clindamycin, fluconazole. The streptococcus anginosus species is 
seen commonly in oral flora, and in abscesses. Patient remained 
very fluid responsive, and was successfully weaned off pressors 
on ___ via IVF resuscitation and transferred to the floor 
where he remained hemodynamically stable with continuation of IV 
abx. 

# Coffee Ground Emesis: Possible ulcers vs. gastritis. Multiple 
episodes at home on ___ at 0200 along with diarrhea and per 
daughter multiple episodes since. Trace guaiac positive stools 
in ED. Patient was initially placed on PPI gtt in ED, 
transitioned to BID IV PPI. A central line and large bore IVs 
were placed. Given no indication of ongoing bleeding, no further 
interventions were performed during hospitalization in regards 
to the coffee ground emesis. Patient had no further episodes of 
hemetemesis and IV PPI was discontinued upon discharge. 

# Tropinemia: Elevated troponin in ED. Heart rate initially > 
140 with question of demand ischemia with ST segment 
depressions. Improved with fluids and reduction in HR. Troponin 
and CKMB remained flat after admission and with improving 
clinical status. 

# Diarrhea: Unclear etiology, likely another reason for 
patient's hypotension. He was volume resuscitated, receiving IVF 
as appropriate. C. dif was negative, and loperamide was provided 
as needed for diarrhea.

# ___: Up from baseline 0.6-0.8. Likely pre-renal in nature 
given hypovolemia, dry on exam, resolved with re-hydration.

# atrial fibrillation vs atrial ectopy: Based on ED ECGs. Also 
with evidence of ectopy with PVCs on telemetry in unit. HR < 100 
in unit, improved from ~ 140 initially in ED. Patient remained 
in sinus HR on the floor with rates in 70-80s.

# goals of care: Given patient's critical illness, goals of care 
were discussed in depth with the patient's daughter (HCP). 
Daughter's faith is very important to her guidance of decisions 
for her father. Via discussions with palliative care team and 
with two intensivist attendings, it was determined that patient 
is a DNR/DNI (CPR/intubation NOT indicated) with no ICU transfer 
due to the risk of harm from these maneuvers far outweighing any 
likely benefit derived from them in this patient. These 
discussions are documented in the chart.

Imaging:
___ CT A/P:  
1. No evidence of aneurysm, pseudoaneurysm or active 
extravasation. 
2. Small volume hemoperitoneum in the upper abdomen and pelvis, 
little changed from the outside hospital CT performed several 
hours earlier. 
3. More localized fluid with surrounding stranding along the 
greater curvature of the stomach, raising the possibility that 
the source of bleeding is from the gastroepiploic territory.  
However, an underlying lesion cannot be excluded, and an MRI is 
recommended for further evaluation when clinically appropriate. 

___ MESENTERIC ARTERIOGRAM:
Abnormal appearance of the left gastric artery treated with 
Gel-Foam 
embolization.  Otherwise, normal arteriograms of the celiac, 
gastroduodenal artery, gastroepiploic artery, and superior 
mesenteric artery, without active extravasation. 

___ MRI Abdomen:
1. Limited exam due to the artifact from splenic artery 
embolization coils.  Diffusion, and pre and post contrast 
sequences cannot be used to assess for tumor given this 
artifact. However, no obvious signal abnormality or other 
finding is seen in the gastric wall on other T1 or T2 weighted 
sequences. 
2. Similar appearance of hematoma along the greater curvature of 
the stomach, intimately associated with the gastric wall, again 
raising the possibility of a gastroepiploic artery or gastric 
wall vascular abnormality as the etiology of this finding. 
3.  Main pancreatic ductal dilation to 6 mm without extrahepatic 
or 
intrahepatic biliary dilation.  A ___ at the ampulla or 
ampullary stenosis is not excluded. 
4.  Bibasilar atelectasis, right greater than left. 
5. 4 mm gallbladder polyp.  No specific follow-up is needed for 
this finding. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to spontaneous hemoperitoneum with 
unknown etiology. CTA did not reveal any extravasation. ___ was 
consulted and an angiogram was performed. They did not see any 
extravasation but noted the left gastric to be abnormal in 
appearance. The left gastric was then gel-foam embolized given 
it's abnormal appearance. An MRI was obtained to rule out any 
gastric masses. It revealed a possibly abnormal gastric wall and 
a possibly stenotic ampulla. Given these findings GI was 
consulted. During this time, she was admitted to the ICU with 
the following course.
Neuro: Her pain was controlled with IV and then subsequently PO 
pain medication. 
CV: hemodynamics were monitored closely. She was intermittently 
tachycardic upon arrival which shortly resolved. 
Resp: She remained stable on room air
GI: Please see above imaging and intervention course. Her diet 
was advanced once her Hcts were stable. 
GU: UOP was adequate with a foley in place
Heme: Serial hematocrits were obtained without need for 
transfusions. 
ID: no acute issues

She was stable for transfer to the floor on ___. Hematocrit 
was stable and subcutaneous heparin was restarted for DVT 
prophylaxis. On HD5 the patient was triggered for hypotension, 
hypoxia, and downtrending hematocrit. Repeat CT of abdomen / 
pelvis showed mild interval decrease in the amount of small 
volume hemoperitoneum.  Chest xray and cardiac enzymes were 
normal. The following day the hematocrit came up on its own. GI 
was consulted for endoscopic evaluation to rule out a gastric 
malignancy that may have led to her bleed. on HD7, the patient 
underwent an EGD, which was normal and showed no findings to 
explain the bleeding. 

Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as 
tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient 
voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient 
ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in 
the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.
.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

# NEUROLOGY:
The patient was observed on long term EEG monitoring which 
revealed no significant changes - at baseline the patient has 
epileptiform discharges and abnormal background.  Push button 
events which were characterized by a scream out and tonic 
posturing with both arms into the air with resolution within a 
minute.  The parents have also been swiping the vagal nerve 
magnet to ablate the seizures which has in general lead to 
resolution in minutes status post swipe.  Repeat CT imaging of 
the head revealed no significant changes.

# ORTHOPEDIC:
Because of concern for your left lower extremity fracture, we 
consulted our orthopedic surgeons to determine if further 
intervention was appropriate, and to determine weight bearing 
status for ambulation.  They recommended continuing conservative 
management through the use of an aircast which has been 
provided.  Her parents have been trained in the used this 
device.

# PULMONARY:
Because of increased respiratory rate, the patient was evaluated 
for pulmonary process or embolus.  CTA was performed with 
revealed no significant perfusion deficit, or intrathoracic 
process.

# INFECTIOUS DISEASE:
Concern was also raised for your left lower extremity swelling 
to possibly be a skin infection known as cellulitis. We began a 
course of antibiotic therapy first with Vancomycin and then with 
Clindamycin, Meropenem, and finally Bactrim.  At the time of 
discharge the patient had no signs of infection.

summary: You were evaluated at ___ for your complaint of increased shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling. Because both of these symptoms can be associated with certain dysfunctions of the heart, we obtained an echocardiogram and blood tests which can reveal decreased activity of the heart muscle. Both of these tests revealed no abnormalities concerning for any dysfunction of the heart. We also reevaluated you with EEG monitoring for any changes concerning for epilepsy; however, we did not see any specific changes which were concerning for new seizure activity on the monitoring performed. Because of concern for your left lower extremity fracture, we consulted our orthopedic surgeons to determine if further intervention was appropriate, and to determine weight bearing status for ambulation. They recommended continuing supportive therapy with the aircast provided. Please adjust the aircast by first releasing the air from the two sides of the cast with the pump. When inflating or replacing the cast in the morning, please administer four (4) pumps in each site on both sides of the cast. Concern was also raised for your left lower extremity swelling to possibly be a skin infection known as cellulitis. We began a course of antibiotic therapy first with Vancomycin and then with Clindamycin, Meropenem, and finally Bactrim. After this course of management, your symptoms improved and no signs of infection were evident.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old lady with a past medical history 
significant for primary biliary cirrhosis (MELD score 9 in 
___, undergoing transplant evaluation, c/b varices, 
encephalopathy) and insulin dependant diabetes who presented to 
the hospital for vascular surgery now s/p left fem-pop bypass. 
Her post operative course has been complicated by hepatic 
encephalopathy, ___ and SBP.

# Peripheral vascular disease. The patient had a left SFA 
occlusion and presented to the hospital on ___ for a scheduled 
left common femoral artery to above-knee popliteal artery bypass 
graft using 6 mm ringed Propaten PTFE.  There were no 
complications during the surgery.  She was part of the silver 
trial, so post-op dressings were removed on POD 3.  She 
initially received Vancomycin, Ciprofloxacin and Flagyl later 
changed to Augmentin. Patient had multiple bed-side debridements 
of a left heel ulcer.  Cx grew coagulase positive staph.  She 
will complete a 4 week course of Augmentin on ___. Her post 
operative course was complicated by hepatic encephalopathy, 
hyponatremia, ___ and SBP. She will follow up with Dr. ___ in 
one month. 

# Oliguric Acute Renal Failure: Creatinine trended up from 
baseline of 0.4-0.9 to 2.5 on POD 5 and urine output decreased. 
Likely ATN likely given the vancomycin level of 47, fluid 
restriction for hyponatremia, diuretics, hypotension post-op and 
diarrhea secondary to lactulose and gradual improvement. 
Initially HRS was also considered given sodium avidity on urine 
lytes and lack of response to albumin. Diuretics (lasix and 
spironolactone) held. Midodrine and Octreotide titrated up to 
max doses, eventually discontinued as Creatinine trende down.  
Creatinine peaked at 4.5 on ___ and began to trend down with 
time and multiple doses of albumin and finally normalized by the 
time of discharge. Discharge Cr 0.9.  

# SBP: Diagnostic paracentesis on ___ showed peritoneal 
fluid with 565 polys. SAAG of 2.7 was consistent with ascites 
from portal hypertension. She received Albumin and Ceftriaxone. 
Repeat Paracentesis on ___ negative for SBP. Patient's 
current secondary prophylaxis coveraged by Augmentin. Once 
Augmentin is discontinued on ___, patient should start 
Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID. 

# Hepatic Encephalopathy: Patient became encephalopathy after 
surgery. A combination of hepatic encephalopathy and general 
anesthesia likely cause. Patient recovered quickly with 
increased lactulose. 

# Primary Biliary Cirrhosis: Decompensated cirrhosis with 
ascites, jaundice, varices with history of GI bleed, and 
encephalopathy. Last EGD on ___ with 3 cords of grade II 
varices. Her MELD score was 9 in ___ and increased to 32 before 
trending down to 17 on discharge. Lactulose, rifaxmin, nadolol 
and ursodiol were continued. Patient had further decompensation 
with INR trending up during this hospital course from 1.2 on 
admission to peak fo 2.1 and 1.7 on discharge.  Lasix 40mg BID 
and Spironolactone 50mg daily were held in the setting of ___. 
Upon discharge restarted at decreased doses of Lasix 20mg daily 
and Spironolactone 50mg daily. The patient is a potential 
transplant candidate, her transplant workup was expedited during 
this hospital course. Necessary workup remaining includes an 
outpatient mammogram. 

# Insulin Dependant Diabetes Mellitus and hypoglycemia: DM 
complicated by neuropathy and nephropathy. Patient at home has 
40 units of NPH in the morning and sliding scale NPH at night. 
Patient had multiple episodes of hypoglycemia during the 
hospital stay. NPH was discontinued and the patient started on 
lantus and humalog sliding scale. Currently on 12 units of 
lantus qHS and insulin sliding scale. 

# Hypothyroidism: Continued levothyroxine 125mcg daily  
  
# HLD: will start Statin therapy at discharge. 

TRANSITION ISSUES: 
- complete transplant workup including out patient mammogram 
- restarted diuretics after ___ at decreased doses. please 
monitor renal function and consider large volume paracentesis 
instead of diuretics if renal function worses
- please follow up left heel ulcer
- please start Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID for secondary SBP 
prophylaxis on ___. Order has already been written. 

MEDICATION CHANGES: 
STARTED Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ PO Q12H - to complete

Brief Hospital Course:
___ man with history notable for anxiety, depression, 
prior left frontal infarct, reported history of learning 
disability, and ___ transferred from OSH after presenting with 
episodic right leg weakness, found to have left parafalcine 
convexal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Follow-up MRI demonstrated 
multiple foci of left frontal and superior parietal lobe 
ischemic infarcts without evidence of significant 
cerebrovascular disease on CTA, overall suggestive of a 
cardioembolic etiology of infarcts. A TTE was performed that 
demonstrated PFO with no valvular or embolic source - in 
discussion with his cardiologist, PFO presence was known and 
found previously. We recommended TEE to better assess his PFO 
for likely closure, though Mr. ___ instead elected to have 
his follow-up evaluation performed as an outpatient at ___ 
___. These findings were discussed with his 
outpatient cardiologist, Dr. ___, at ___, who 
agreed to obtain follow-up TEE, Duplex venous ultrasound of the 
lower extremities, and cardiac monitoring to assess for 
paroxysmal atrial fibrillation following discharge from ___. 
MRV or CTV of the pelvis may also be considered to assess for 
DVTs. In the meantime, aspirin 81 mg daily and atorvastatin 40 
mg daily were started for secondary stroke prevention.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
1. Outpatient transesophageal echocardiogram with consideration 
for PFO closure.
2. Outpatient Duplex venous ultrasound of the lower extremities; 
consider CTV/MRV pelvis if negative to assess for DVT.
3. Outpatient cardiac monitoring for 30 days to assess for 
paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
4. Ongoing medication adherence counseling.
5. Cardiology Follow up
6. Neurology Follow up

summary: You were admitted to ___ for evaluation of intermittent right leg weakness. Your initial CT scan showed a small area of bleeding on the surface of your brain, and a follow up MRI of your head showed signs of an old stroke as well as multiple small new strokes. As your blood vessel imaging did not show signs of significant vascular disease, it is likely that the clots leading to your strokes came from your heart. In discussing with your outpatient cardiologist, you were previously found to have a connection between your heart chambers (patent foramen ovale - PFO) that may predispose you to strokes. An ultrasound of your heart (transthoracic echocardiogram) was performed with prelim read confirming the PFO with no other valvular abnormalities. We strongly recommended a follow-up endoscopic study (transesophageal echocardiogram), but you instead elected to have this procedure done as an outpatient. This was discussed with your cardiologist, who will follow up with you to schedule the transesopagheal echocardiogram, ultrasound studies of your legs, and heart rhythm monitoring. In the meantime, we again started you on aspirin and a cholesterol medication (atorvastatin) to reduce your risk of future strokes.

Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with PMH alpha 
1antitrypsin deficiency, severe emphysema, DMI w/ h/o convulsion 
due to hypoglycemia, diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy, 
prostate cancer s/p TURP and chemo, bipolar d/o, depression, p/w

medicine service for hypoxia and atrial fibrillation. His 
hypoxia improved with diuresis, but still occurred with 
ambulation. His afib was controlled with metoprolol. He was 
discharged home. 

# Hypoxia
# COPD due to alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency with acute 
exacerbation
Patient with new-onset hypoxia while inpatient. Cause is likely 
multifactorial. Likely from splinting from pain + pulmonary 
edema RVR and IVF + COPD exacerbation. CTA was negative for PE. 
Patient was given one dose of Lasix for diuresis. He was given 
incentive spirometer and DuoNebs. He was continued on tiotropium 
daily, and fluticasone/salmeterol BID. His oxygen requirement at 
rest gradually resolved during hospitalization, however he was 
still desatting on ambulation at time of discharge, and was 
discharged with home O2. Please continue to monitor ambulatory 
oxygenation. 

# Afib 
# Mild right ventricle hypokinesis
Patient went into afib with RVR two separate times during the 
hospitalization that broke with 5mg IV metoprolol. His rates 
were controlled on metoprolol succinate 25mg daily. This appears 
to be newly diagnosed afib. Trigger likely pain from fall and 
volume overload given fluids patient received in ED. However, 
given his comorbidities, it's also possible that patient has had 
afib for quite some time and has just been undiagnosed. 
CHADSVASC=4. Echo with EF 55%, mild right ventricle. 
hypokinesis. Cardiology was consulted. Given his history of 
falls, he was not discharged on anticoagulation. He should 
follow-up with an outpatient cardiologist for a further 
discussion of the risks and benefits of anticoagulation. He was 
also discharged with ___ of Hearts monitor to assess burden of 
afib. 

# Chest wall pain 
# Fall and R ___ rib fractures 
ACS evaluated the patient and has signed off. Pain was well 
controlled with Tylenol, a lidocaine patch, and his home 
gabapentin. 

# DMI 
# Hyperglycemia

hypoglycemia as he has history of convulsions and syncope from 
hypoglycemia. ___ Diabetes team followed him during his 
hospitalization and changed insulin regimen as needed. Of note, 
patient did take his home insulin on at least one occasion, even 
though he was instructed not to administer his own insulin while 
in the hospital.
